<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> No chance. I've seen what the gods have in store for us all.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Maybe you're right. I'll start by defending my wine barrel. I'll be right back.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Wh..what.. Maybe you're right. I need to go home and sleep..
And in the eighth hour of the third night, death came in the dark and left a swath of unbelievers to rot on the ground! It was a message! A portent of the new god who comes to the land!
For the unbelievers, he will come as a dark giant with fiery eyes and unending thirst for blood; but for those who believe, he shall be the gentle cowherd, who protects his followers.
I don't want to die! I shall follow this new god. What is his name?
That has not been revealed to me yet. But follow me and do as I say, and the god who arises shall look on you favorably.
What lies you spread! I will listen to no more of your foolishness, Piper.
Then damnation be upon your head, fool woman! You will be dead within the week. This much has the new god shown me.
Even you, <FirstName>, shall have to choose! Will you doom yourself and die like farmer Hol, or will you repent of your ways and follow me?
You walk on the dark path, <FirstName>. I foresee your death. It is imminent. Seek the new god, if you would avoid the inevitable!
He comes to purge the wicked! To follow him, give up this worldly life, with all of the trappings of success and give everything to him!
What? Give up everything I have worked so hard to gain? You really are insane! I am going to speak to the mayor about this.
But what about old Hol Halstrom? He called Piper a fool and now he's dead!
Yeah. Me no want to be dead. Me will follow new god. Me got nothing to give up anyway.
Only a few shall believe and only a few shall be saved! The rest of you will die in the darkness! Soon he comes! Soon he comes!
No! Do not be tricked, my followers, by this unbeliever and <his/her> lies. I am the prophet of the new god!
All praise and worship to the new god and his prophet!
Yes, my faithful cattle! You shall be protected by the new god, for he is the cowherd who drives off the wolf!
There will be panic and pain aplenty when the new god destroys the unbelievers! Verily, they shall all pay with their blood and souls.
It is your words that are blasphemous and you shall pay with darkness and destruction. I foresee your death!
No, the new god protected me from the kobolds! Not one came near my precious shack! All praise to the new god!
I was chosen to save this village from eternal damnation. If they continue down the path into darkness, all will be lost.
If we do not repent, then we shall be struck by a plague, just as Neverwinter has been. They too will heed the warnings of the new god, or be destroyed.
Never before have the people been in such danger. I am the prophet who comes before. When the new god rises, I shall lead the people to him, and we shall all fall down in worship and praise.
There is nothing that godless old fool could have to say to me that my followers cannot also hear. Go on then and make your threats!
Do not forget the fate of those who mock me! Forget not the death of Hol Halstrom!
Push me, shove me, kick me, beat me; I shall rise again, stronger than ever, to proclaim the coming of the new god. Try to drive the truth from this village, at peril of your own soul!
You walk the path of darkness! Someday soon death will come for you.
I told you, the new god will preserve me from harm! There is nothing you can do to me!
It is you who shall die! I smite you in the name of the new god, whatever his name will be!
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> You think you can be rid of me that easily? The prophet of the new god sees through your tricks. Be gone foul tempter!
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> You may be right. The others of this town will not turn from their dark paths. But where would I go? Who needs to know of the coming god?
Waterdeep? Millions of souls needing to be saved! Yes, that would be a task worthy of the prophet of the new god!
Neverwinter? Yes, I had heard they are troubled by a plague. Surely that is the work of the new god, to weed out the evil in that city.
But that is fairly far away, and I will need provisions for such a trip, and how will I live when I get there? No, it is too difficult. I will stay here.
That is fairly close, but I will need provisions for such a trip, and how will I live when I get there? No, it is too difficult. I will stay here.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Such fair dealing from you, perhaps you really are a believer. I must make haste. Others need me!
Such fair dealing from you, perhaps you really are a believer. I must make haste. Others need me!
I have explained how the kobolds have come as a warning to the fools on the path of darkness. You are the one who is confused!
Nay! The new god directed that weapon and struck down the one who despised his prophet! It was a deliberate act!
I was the one who found Hol's corpse. The neck was nearly severed and there were many wounds on his body! The new god must have hated him!
And that shall be the most certain outcome of those who flaunt their disbelief in the new god! Repent or be destroyed!
Even the truth seems like nonsense to those who have not the wisdom to see what should be plainly evident!
It is a testament of his anger! All who deny him shall face his wrath!
The strong, stubborn farmer, slaughtered by an old wisp like me? I don't think so. Besides I have no weapon to kill him with! The kobolds merely followed the new god's orders!
All of the new god's enemies shall perish at his coming. Only the wisest and most fortunate will be brought into his kingdom, which shall last for all eternity!
There are no words that can stop the truth that the new god is coming. Repent and follow me!
No. Only Hol. He was the target of the new god's vengeance!
All of the new god's enemies shall perish at his coming. Only the wisest and most fortunate will be brought into his kingdom, which shall last for all eternity!
I didn't kill him! It wasn't me, I swear! I only found his corpse and messed it up a bit! I promise!
No, I never did! It wasn't me, I swear! I only found his corpse and messed it up a bit! I promise!
You defiled Hol's corpse? He was my friend! I can't believe this.
You disgust me! I think I had better go apologize to Hol's widow and see how she is doing.
We all should do that. Piper, you are filth. No one will ever believe your lies again.
Gone! No! They will hurt me. Yes, they will hurt me. I must leave. Run, run, run! Blast you, <FirstName>! I shall not forgive you for this!
Before now, I felt the stirrings of prophecy, but never understood what it was I felt. Now my mind has been opened to the wisdom of the new god.
The god speaks to him! He is the new god's holy man!
Yes, the god speaks to me, and you must all listen to his wisdom as it pours forth onto you, like a fountain washing you clean! This village needs me!
What would you know of the right way or the wrong way to help this village? You and your fellow students live a life of luxury up in your precious school.
What... what could I possibly do to help this village when all my life I have had nothing? You have been trained. You have weapons! All I have is my prophecies!
And you... you would take them away from me? The new god... the new god will strike you and your unbelieving friends down!
I... I do not know. If I had my old sword and the guards would train me, then I could become a guard too. But... to abandon the new god... but, if I could have my old sword...
Yes, my shiny old sword which I pawned to the smith! I have missed my dear old sword. Then I could become a guard and save the village. Then people would respect me, like a real hero!
But I don't have my sword! No, and until I have my sword, my weapon must be... the new god! Yes! The new god comes, with a shiny new sword!
<StartAction>[He whispers.]</Start> I suppose I could just talk to myself about him, if that would help.
But you have to bring me my sword! Until then, I shall spread the news of the new god!
The doubters always claim that miraculous events are mere luck. But we know better! The new god chose me as his voice and gave me a clear perception of the world.
Speak no more to me! There is nothing you can say to convince me! Begone, young adventurer! Death shall find you soon enough!
It shall avail you nothing! Try what you want, but there is no moving me!
The new god rises more powerful than all the other gods! I see it now! You have cleared my clouded vision! The new god comes to sweep all the other gods away.
The one true god! The one true god!
Yes! Your words which were meant to hinder me have helped instead!
Of course they were! When the god comes he will demand tribute. It is only fitting that he send his minions ahead to capture objects of power!
The new god is coming in glory! We worship his mighty prophet who shines a light on the dark words of the unbeliever!
You see! Your doubting words only serve to bolster my cause! You have strayed from the path of righteousness, turn, turn to the new god!
There is nothing you can say that can drive the truth from our fair village. When the new god rises, you and all your fellow students will bow before him, or you will die!
He comes I tell you! Fall on your knees and weep for forgiveness, before the darkness claims your immortal soul!
I am sorry I followed the dark path! I have committed many indiscretions, and I have had impure thoughts!
He sees the corruption in your body, but the innocence of your soul is made known by your confession! Grovel at my feet and the new god shall forgive you for your past!
And the faithful shall be saved, but those who lack faith shall...
Die?
Yes! Those who lack faith shall die most horrible deaths.
Oh! That is my beautiful sword! Now I can become a guard and help save the village. And the new god will be... oh, right... my promise.
That's right, there is no new god. Don't worry... he will not be showing up in two weeks, five hours and twenty three minutes to kill everyone. Go about your business. Nothing to see here.
But what about all the prophesies? Are you sure you made them up?
Yes, yes, they are all made up. Bye, bye now. Run along.
You lucky you got that sword or you be joining you fake god.
Repent of your wickedness! Give yourself to the new god! Worship the prophet of the new god, and you shall be cleansed!
link
No really - take this sword and together we can help defend Hilltop from anything the gods send against us.
Right. Goodbye.
I could use a good laugh. Tell me about this 'god'.
Tell me more about this new god.
Maybe I should collect the gold for the new god.
You are going to cause more panic with such stories.
You should not spread such blasphemy.
Did one of the kobolds hit you in the head?
What are you trying to do, old man?
I need to speak to you in private, on behalf of the mayor.
I want nothing more to do with you.
You can leave Hilltop or the next god you see will be in hell!
Leave or die.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> I think you have done all you can for Hilltop. Others need to be warned.
So many people live in Waterdeep, surely some of them are worthy of saving.
Neverwinter always has troubles. Perhaps they need your wisdom.
Silverymoon is not so far away. I hear they believe almost anything there.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> The gods will provide for one as righteous as you.
I will give you ten gold, which should help you on your way.
I think you have been confused by the kobold attack.
Hol died because he was in the wrong place at the wrong time. It was coincidence.
How can you people believe such nonsense?
Why would a god of good defile a corpse in such a way?
Maybe you killed him, Piper!
You must stop this foolishness now.
Did any of the other corpses have such wounds?
That is strange. Did any of the other corpses have such wounds?
You killed him, Piper, so I shall kill you!
Tell us what truly happened, old man!
You killed him, didn't you?
Did you have anything to do with his death, Piper?
You have made many predictions in the past that weren't true.
What it needs is another corpse; maybe yours!
There is need for you in this village, but you go about it all wrong.
What if I helped you, so you could protect the town?
If I get your sword back will you stop ranting about this new god?
It was luck and that is all. You were bound to get one right eventually.
Perhaps we should try something else?
Don't you think the local priest would know if there was a new god?
Maybe I can explain a different way.
The kobolds were thieves, sent to steal artifacts from Drogan's school.
Well, this is getting us nowhere.
Goodbye.
I have your sword.
Where were Drogan and <StartAction>[hic]</Start> his big heroes when the villagers were getting murdered? Sho much <StartAction>[hic]</Start> for relying on them for help.
Sir! You are talking to one right now!
I don't know what <StartAction>[hic]</Start> you're talking about Haniah. Thish is just my old friend Pat!
I wish you would just go lie down and rest, sir.
You know, I'm the mayor here? Damn <StartAction>[hic]</Start> damn right I am. And in a dinky, little village like thish, you would <StartAction>[hic]</Start> think that would earn me shome reshpect.
Everyone respects you, sir. Well, except when you are in this condition.
Doesh anyone have a... <StartAction>[hic]</Start> another bottle of wine? I <StartAction>[hic]</Start> sheem to be right out.
I think you have had enough, sir.
There'sh never enough. Not when you really <StartAction>[hic]</Start> need it. Like when my wife died... never enough.
Those damn kobolds think <StartAction>[hic]</Start> that they can just march into my town and kill <StartAction>[hic]</Start> my villagers off, do they? Well, jusht let them try that again!
We would rather they just stayed away, sir.
Too late, Haniah! Too <StartAction>[hic]</Start> late. <StartAction>[Sob]</Start>
Would you stop swaying back and <StartAction>[hic]</Start> forth! You're making me <StartAction>[hic]</Start> dizzy.
Sir, you are the one who is swaying.
Don't be <StartAction>[hic]</Start> ridiculoush. Why would I be shwaying?
Because you are drunk, sir.
Oh ya! I <StartAction>[hic]</Start> forgot. Somebody fetch me more wine!
There'sh nobody who understands me <StartAction>[hic]</Start>, escept for Haniah <StartAction>[hic]</Start>. She'sh sho helpful. Like a daughter to me. Yesh shir! <StartAction>[hic]</Start>
Thank you, sir. Maybe you should get a little rest?
Nonshensh! My people need me!
<StartAction>[Sob]</Start>... <StartAction>[sigh]</Start>... I... uh... more wine pleashe...<StartAction>[hic]</Start>.
The wolf looks at you with intelligent eyes. The fact that it bares its teeth and growls slightly tells you it does not care for what it sees.
The wolf pulls its ears back as you approach, obviously not caring for your presence.
The wolf regards you with mild curiosity and does not shy away from you.
This handsome wolf is Farghan's animal companion. She regards you with intelligent, wary eyes and sends an empathetic greeting.
She acknowledges your departure and returns to her routine.
She sends warm thoughts to you and returns her attention to her new mate.
The wolf seems genuinely surprised that you know of this. She buried an item of her master's two moons ago to challenge the worth of the local canines.
None of the male dogs have been able to find the item; however, and sadly she thinks they never will. None of them will make a worthy mate.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> She mulls over the decision for a moment before finally deciding that there is no harm in telling you... the local canines will never find it, anyway.
The item is buried underneath a group of rocks that lay behind a human building that smells of iron and fire.
The wolf is pleased by your manners. She bids you luck on your hunt.
She relates that the item belonged to her master. It smelled strongly of nature and magic... but it was something her master no longer used.
She knows little else about it, and is glad that her master did not miss it.
The wolf relates to you that there is little information that she could offer that you would find useful. Her interests are a wolf's interests and not <race>.
She tells you, for instance, that there are no worthy mates within the human village. Small canines with weak minds only. She finds this very sad.
The wolf empathetically sends a polite refusal. When the time comes, she insists, her master will assist her.
She says also that her attentions for the moment are wrapped up in her new mate. Apparently one of the local dogs was worthy enough after all.
The wolf responds to your empathic communication with images from her mind. She explains that she fought and killed two of the kobold creatures at her master's side earlier.
After the battle, however, her master brought her back inside and she was not able to give chase to the creatures. She does not know where they went, sadly.
You fish into your pack for a few strips of dried meat. The wolf sniffs at them delicately but refuses to partake.
<StartAction>Bid the wolf farewell.</Start>
<StartAction>Ask her about the secret she buried.</Start>
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> <StartAction>Ask where she buried this item.</Start>
<StartAction>Thank her for the information.</Start>
<StartAction>Ask her what item she buried.</Start>
<StartAction>Ask the wolf for any useful information it might have.</Start>
<StartAction>Ask her if you can help find her a mate.</Start>
<StartAction>Ask the wolf for information on the kobolds' passing.</Start>
<StartAction>Give the wolf a snack.</Start>
Your powers have saved me, <FirstName>.
Oh... uh... help me. I feel so weak...
Thank god you've come, <FirstName>. Please...Tynan is upstairs and I saw a kobold go up there too.
Aaarrrgghhh!
<StartAction>[Gasp!]</Start> Drogan had better never find out you have this vicious streak, <FirstName>. As a harper, he would have to stop you.
I never would have thought you had it in you, <FirstName>. I guess school is out.
Ohh, the pain!
Your powers have saved me...
Ohhh, thank you, that's much better.
<StartAction>[He drinks the potion.]</Start>
Thank you, <FirstName>, that feels much better. We should hurry, if we are to save Tynan.
Quickly... please!
Hello <FirstName>. Is... is Tynan alive still? Did you... kill the kobold?
<StartAction>[sob]</Start> Poor Tynan, butchered before he even had a chance to live. And sweet Nora, how will she recover from this?
I... I do not know how to tell her. I... I must go upstairs and wrap Tynan's little corpse. I do not want Nora to see him like this.
I... cannot hold him. I am too... weak. Please... please take him out to Nora... and tell her... I... I loved her.
Yes, I was collecting our valuables downstairs when I was attacked. Here, take this.
We need to hurry if we are to stand a chance.
Thank you for rescuing my child. I will stay here and take care of him. Would you please go and tell my wife?
But... but why would you do that? I can take care of Tynan.
I cannot let you do that, <FirstName>. I have heard rumors that you have a dark nature, and I cannot let you take my child. Now give him back or I will have to kill you.
Then die, foul fiend!
Thank you. Now please go tell my wife her son and husband are safe.
I would feel more comfortable if you just give my baby back. I do not want him taken outside right now. Not when there might be more kobolds on the loose.
Thank you. You are a kind soul.
Thank you for all that you have done for us, <FirstName>. I am very grateful.
Be quiet, I don't know if there are more kobolds around here.
At least you are alive.
Are you ok?
<StartAction>[Coup de gras]</Start> Widows are much easier to manipulate. See you in hell.
<StartCheck>[Heal]</Start> Hold still; let me treat you with this healing kit.
<StartAction>[Lay on Hands]</Start> Hold still; let me treat you.
<StartAction>[Use a spell or ability to Cure Adam.]</Start> Hold still, let me treat you.
Take this healing potion; you look like you need it more than I.
Yes, let's go.
I'll see what I can do...
I am so terribly sorry.
Here is your child...
The kobold will release your child in exchange for a gem, do you have any?
No, I think I will keep the child.
I think I will keep him.
No, he is mine now.
Fine. Take your babe. He sure smells awful anyways.
I want to take him to his mother.
Alright, I will do that.
The corpse of Adam Blake lies on the floor of his house. He has been pierced repeatedly by kobold swords.
A fair <quarterday> to you, <FirstName>. Is there something I can do for you?
I wish both you and your Master Drogan the best of luck, then.
Certainly. As you're a student of Drogan's, naturally I'll give you a good deal on any of my merchandise.
Oh, I mostly sell herbs and others things that come from nature. Plus goods that are useful to druids like myself.
You've been here before, <FirstName>. I mostly sell herbs and things that come from nature. Plus other goods that would interest a druid like yourself.
There were plenty just outside my door not long ago. I helped the guards to fight them until they were driven off, thankfully.
Other than those, I only know of a group that ran down from the north. I understand they left Hilltop by the gate.
Hopefully they don't come back. I've never seen kobolds be so aggressive.
What's this? Oh, my old ring, is it? Well, now, I thought Bethsheba had carried that off months ago and buried it somewhere.
If she was impressed enough with you to tell you where it was, <FirstName>, you're welcome to keep it. Truly I don't need it anymore.
Greetings to you, <FirstName>. Shame about your Master Drogan. Evil creatures those kobolds are. Is he at all better?
Well, if there's anything I can do to help him, don't hesitate to ask.
Ahhh, <FirstName>, is it? It's good to see you're unharmed. A nasty business with these kobolds. I hope that Master Drogan's well, also?
That's a fine attitude to have, you being one of his students. I hope that is merely bravado and not a lack of appreciation for all Drogan has done for you.
Is there something else I can do for you, <FirstName>?
Poisoned! By the gods, those kobolds are foul creatures, aren't they? Well, then... do you know what sorts of herbs you need exactly?
Ah, good, good. Drogan has been a fine addition to this town ever since his arrival. I'd hate to see anything happen to him.
Well, that's good news at least. There's been so little as of late. Thank you for telling me, <FirstName>.
That's terrible! If there's anything I can do to help him, don't hesitate to let me know. Terrible, evil little creatures those kobolds are!
Of course I'll help if I can. What is it I can do?
Well... if you're certain. Should that change, don't hesitate to ask.
<StartCheck>[Failed]</Start> Well, certainly I... hmmm. I've heard the odd tale about you, <FirstName>, and I won't fall for your crafty tricks. Is there another way I can help?
<StartCheck>[Failed]</Start> Oh dear. Well certainly I'll offer... wait. You're trying to trick me, aren't you? Sneaky <boy/girl>. Is there any *other* way I can help?
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Oh dear. Well certainly I'll offer what I can. Here... take this. Is there anything else I can do for him?
I'm afraid I've given away all the tressym tongue and charcoal I had, I'm sorry. I'm really not sure where you could go to get more.
That's odd. Here's the charcoal you need... but I seem to be out of tressym tongue. I could have sworn I had some.
That's odd. Here's the tressym tongue you need... but I seem to be out of charcoal. I could have sworn I had some.
That's odd. I could have sworn I had some tressym tongue and charcoal... but it's all gone.
Hmmm. I do happen to have some tressym tongue and charcoal on me. Here... take them, no charge of course.
As for helmthorn berries, you could try asking Mara at the tavern if she still has some. I sold her the last of my stock a week ago.
Oh dear. She wasn't hurt during the attack, was she? Damnable kobolds! Well... all I can suggest is that you look around her kitchen, sorry.
You do? Well that solves that, then. I hope the remedy works.
No, thanks.
I'd like to see what you have in stock.
What kinds of things do you sell here?
I should go.
Have you seen any kobolds in the area?
I found this ring outside. Does it belong to you?
Yes, he's recovering... just not completely well yet.
No, he's not. In fact, that's why I'm here... I need some herbs for him.
He wasn't the last time I saw him, no.
I could not care less. I have other things to worry about.
I need some herbs for Master Drogan: he's been poisoned.
Tressym tongue, charcoal and helmthorn berries.
He was alive, last time I checked.
He was poisoned, but he's recovering nicely now.
No, he's not. He was poisoned during a kobold attack.
That's actually why I'm here. He's been poisoned.
Never mind.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> He needs a bunch of your equipment. Free of charge, I assume?
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> You could donate some coin. The cure is very expensive.
No, never mind.
I need some herbs. Tressym tongue, charcoal and helmthorn berries.
I'll try that, thanks.
Mara's actually not at the tavern anymore...
I really don't think I'll be asking Mara anything, actually.
I already have some helmthorn berries, thanks.
You gots me a shiny?
Yip, yip! Me stole the baby, stupid <race> <man/woman>! Me gots control of you now, yip!
Me not think so, yip! Kobolds love them children, so do you. If you want it, yip, you must gives me shiny gem in return.
Yip, me saw human downstairs had nice shiny. You gets and gives to me. Yip, yip!
Yip! Me like songs! You play, that good idea.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> What? Yip? What happen? Yip, you have the baby! Oh no, me was tricked. Now you pay for that!
Me give baby to you.
Me leave peacefully.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Yip! You not so tough and me have baby! Why should me ever just give baby for nothing, yip? You go get me shiny now!
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Yip, that be stupid! No try that again, yip, or me eat baby!
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Yip! No, stupid! Now me have to kill you!
Yip! Yes, go get shiny! Go quick, me gettin' hungry.
Yip, yip, yip! Me so happy, me is now going. You take smelly baby! Him make big stink.
Someone stole the gem I had. Do you have one, <FirstName>? I swear I will pay you back, someday.
Yip! No! Me kill you both!
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> <FirstName>, I saw you take it, but I did not want to say anything, because I needed your help!
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Then I fear my child is doomed. Kobold, would you allow my friend here to go and look for a gem?
Him go get shiny? Yip! Okay, that be good. Me wait here.
We have no choice, <FirstName>. Please, just trade it to the kobold for my child!
I have a gem. If I give it to you, do you promise to give my son back?
Yip, yes, me will trade! You give me shiny.
There, now give my son back.
Die, sneaky beastie!
Give me the baby and I promise you a quick, painless death.
If you kill the child, I will have to kill you.
Just give me the baby and I will let you go.
The babe looks upset, I will play a song to calm it.
<StartAction>[Fascinate kobold then steal the baby.]</Start>
<StartAction>[Cast Charm Spell]</Start> You will give the baby to me.
You will leave peacefully.
<StartAction>[Persuade]</Start> Give me the baby or die, now!
I would rather just kill you and take the baby.
Ok... here you...<StartAction>[Snatch the baby from the kobold]</Start>
I will kill you first.
Just give me the baby!
Oops, sorry bout that, I slipped..
I'll go get one.
Here's a nice shiny gem. Now give me that child!
Kill it now, while we have it cornered!
I have a better idea. <StartAction>[Snatch the baby from the kobold.]</Start>
<StartCheck>[Persuade - Lie]</Start> No, I don't have any gems.
Fine. Take the gem, but give us the child.
Yes, I have one, but I don't trust the kobold.
Yes, I have one. Here, take it and give the child back.
The dog bares its teeth and growls, obviously alarmed by your approach.
The dog wags its tail with obvious uncertainty and shies away from you.
The dog looks at you curiously. It seems friendly enough.
The dog greets you warmly, thinking pleasant thoughts of his new mate Bethsheva.
Hey! Leave my stuff alone! Stop you thief!
Get out of my hovel, you beasts! Leave me alone! Oh, it's just you, <FirstName>. When my locked door suddenly opened, I thought the kobolds were back.
If you are hunting kobolds, there's none in here. THEY got the point when they found the door locked and left. Just goes to show, I suppose. So, is the fighting done?
Lousy, snooping adventurers; always going into other people's homes and stealing their stuff.
Oh, right then. I think I will. Just to be safe.
What ever. Just be gone.
You bashed down my door, so I have nothing to stop any other hungry monsters from wandering into my house and having a little Toman snack, and now you just want to chat a little? Hmm?
Anything else, or has the stench of my poverty finally driven you off?
I suppose so, if you really want to. I imagine it might cost me two gold pieces to replace it, though it did need replacing anyways. The wood was getting a little soft.
Oh, never mind. I know where there's a little abandoned cabin, not too far from here. I can just take the door off of it. It's in better shape than mine was anyways. What do you want?
Nothing much recently, unless you include the Red Wizard who came to town. I tremble at the thought of those Thayvians coming here. Evil folk they are.
Last I heard, the mayor and his assistant were going to throw him out of town. I don't know what happened though, the kobolds attacked before he got an audience with the mayor.
My guess is he'll be headed out of town. Good riddance and none too soon if you ask me! Other than that, there's the halfling caravan and that's about all I know.
Little thieves, that's what they are! Good thing I don't have nothing for them to steal. I have kept my distance, just in case though. I don't know why they're here.
I think you would get along with them. You could pick each other's pockets and locks and all that sort of nonsense. For a man like me, I avoid getting to close, just in case.
Well, they look a fair bit like you, which makes sense I suppose. I have kept my distance from them, since some around here claim they're just a bunch of thieves anyways.
I don't know anything more about them, but you can go speak to them if you wish. Their caravan is right down the road from here. Anything else?
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> You are such a bad liar. You just came here to rob me. So why don't you go ahead and do that? I don't have hardly anything other than this hovel.
Maybe you should just kill me and loot my home! Maybe you'll even find a couple of silver pieces!
Uh... oh, you wouldn't really do that would you? I don't want to die. But I really am poor. I am just a little overwrought, what with the attack and all. Any other questions?
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> It's about time somebody did something to protect us poor citizens. I'm glad to hear the mayor is taking steps.
Here is my gold piece. That's all I have left. Took me a year to save up that much, but I am happy to part with it, if it goes towards saving my life.
Any other questions?
This is a one-road village. You have lived here for years. What could you possibly need directions to?
Well, I should hope not! Is there anything else?
Right across the road. Look for the sign that says 'Blacksmith'. How hard can this be?
Right across the road. Look for the sign that says 'Herbalist', unless Drogan never taught you to read.
Right across the street from the Community Hall.
Right next door in the Community Hall. What else?
You picked the lock to my door so you could loot my hovel, probably broke the lock too, and now you just want to have a little chat? Hmm?
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Hey, don't you threaten me. I'm good friends with the mayor and I'm on speaking terms with Drogan. You little upstarts don't worry me none.
Just leave me alone. You'll get yours someday!
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Don't hurt me, please. I didn't do anything wrong! Why are you robbing me? I'm just a poor, lonely guy.
I... I guess I can give you my gold piece. That's all I have though. I would threaten to tell Drogan, but I guess you would hurt me if I did. I'll keep my mouth shut, I promise.
Just don't hurt me. Please just go away.
With what, my carving knife? Give me a break. There are plenty of adventurers around here, including yourself. I wouldn't stand a chance. So is the fighting done or not?
Oh, I see you came back. What do you want now?
Yes. Off you go to rob some other poor sap.
Just go away. I don't want to talk to you.
I cannot believe I got kicked out my house by that Red Wizard. He had some kind of permit from the mayor, but where will I sleep?
Yes, goodbye.
No, you might want to continue cowering in here for a while.
Goodbye.
I want to ask you some questions.
That's all my questions.
Sorry, can I fix the door or pay you for the damage?
Besides the attack, what has happened recently?
Tell me about the halflings.
<StartCheck>[Persuade - Lie]</Start>So have you heard about the new Kobold Defense Tax?
I need directions.
Maybe I don't need directions after all.
Where is the blacksmith?
Where is the herbalist?
Where is the local tavern?
Where would I find the mayor?
I don't need any more directions.
<StartCheck>[Persuade - Intimidate]</Start> Not for you, unless I see some gold!
Why didn't you come out and help drive off the attack?
Goodbye.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Don't mind him. My brother don't talk much. Especially not today, with all the fighting and such.
Yes? What is it? What brings you to Daschnaya's little wagon, hmm?
And so you should. Off with you, then.
I am Daschnaya, as I said. If you've come for a reading, you'll have to run along. I've no cards to ply my trade with, thanks to the kobold thieves.
Are you deaf, <man/woman>? A reading of your future, yes. I have the gift of foresight... for all the good it does me without my cards.
Now shoo. Be off. Daschnaya's wagon is small enough without crowding it.
Oh? So you do, so you do. So it's you after all, is it? I should have recognized you for who you are. Well, well, it's done.
I suppose you'll be wanting a reward for returning my cards to me, yes? What shall it be? What does the <race> <man/woman> wish?
Ah, yes, Daschnaya does have a few coins. Not enough to call a fortune, and no doubt less than half what a greedy <man/woman> would wish.
Of far more worth is information... such as information of your future. Would you not consider that in trade, instead?
Then gold you shall have. And here it is... all that I possess which the kobolds did not take for the one thing I prize which they did.
So there it is done. You have my payment and my thanks. Now we are quits, you and I. May the future find you well.
No doubt she did. Very well, dear <boy/girl>... Daschnaya is willing to look into your future, if that is your true wish. Is it?
Such a sweet <boy/girl> you are. Thank you most kindly. Are you sure you will not allow me to do a brief reading for you? Free of charge?
Believing is not the same thing as truth... but knowledge will come whether you wish it or not. As it will for you, in time, so be it.
As you wish, as you wish. Daschnaya is not one to force knowledge on one who does not wish it.
I thank you for returning an old fortune-teller's cards to her. May the future find you well, dear <boy/girl>.
Ahhh, good. Good! Allow Daschnaya to prepare, dear <boy/girl>, and we shall see what the future holds, eh?
Hmmm. Most interesting... Daschnaya sees a long road ahead before you, fraught with perils. Something valuable has been stolen and you seek to find it.
It lies in the hands of one who... who hides in a village to the east. But this one is not of that village. Frightened, is he, frightened and weak.
He will ask your help, dear <boy/girl>, and you must not refuse it should you wish to gain what was stolen.
And you must gain it back. It is most dangerous. More than anything else that was taken. It must not fall into her hands!
I... know not. I cannot look upon the face of the one who seeks what you seek, and I do not know why. The future is closed.
That is all I can say... except that finding what you seek is only the beginning. Be wary, young one... be wary.
Heed what I say or do not, that is not my concern. You have been given the knowledge; do with it as you will.
Now I tire. You have my thanks and we are quits. Daschnaya would go to bed... and you have an adventure before you. I hope the future finds you well.
Daschnaya sees less than she would like, but often more than she should. I can only hope my pitiful skill has offered you some insight.
Yes? What is it? Why does one of the large folk stumble into Daschnaya's little wagon?
Yes? What is it? A halfling, but not one of us, eh? Why do you come to see Daschnaya?
I've no time or energy for readings today, young <man/woman>. Come back another day when Daschnaya can help you.
You have returned my cards to me and for that Daschnaya is grateful. Now leave an old halfling woman to her peace.
I should go.
Who are you?
A reading?
Very well. I'll go.
I have your cards, here.
Anything of value. Cough it up or die, woman.
Coin would be fine. Or gems, jewels, anything valuable.
Your valuables for your life. Now that's a fair trade.
I prize gold much more highly.
Alright. But make it good.
Katriana mentioned something about a reading...
Actually, I'd prefer something more substantial as a reward.
Yes, I'd like that.
Perhaps not. But take the cards anyway, they're yours.
I need no reward. The cards are yours.
I do not believe in your hedge magics.
No. I've no interest in such a thing.
Very well. That's very kind of you.
Whose hands?
That's it? I should cut your throat for giving me that garbage!
Well, thanks for nothing.
Thank you, Daschnaya.
Ho there! Best watch your step, friend... there's kobold entrails all about.
Best of luck to you, then, friend.
Alright. Fare you well, big 'un.
You'd probably be better off talking to Katriana. She heads the caravan, you know. But, um, you can ask me whatever you like.
You mean other than the ones we chased out? Yes, I think so. Torias said he saw some running down from the north a while ago. Went through the gate.
It's not that unusual. It's no different than any other caravan that comes through here, I bet.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Well, okay. It's probably smaller, that's true.
Katriana, of course. Go on and talk to her, if you like.
East, I think. Across the Anauroch Desert. But not until everyone's healed up properly, I think.
Maybe so. No reason we can't be merchants at the same time.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
True. Like my brother says, big 'uns always assume we're a bunch of thieves so trading's the only way to be accepted anywhere.
Naw. Not to say I haven't nipped the pocket of a big 'un or two, right friend? Heh.
Now that's a nasty thing for a big 'un to say. Certainly not!
Same thing that happened everywhere else in Hilltop, it looks like: we got attacked by kobolds. Scaly buggers figured they could rob us blind.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Yes, brother, I know. We showed them good. Serves them right for underestimating halfling might.
Well... yeah, they did. They didn't get as much as they might have liked, but they got away with some of our supplies.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
You know, you're right, brother. Hey friend... if you want to help us out, talk to Katriana.
Sounds good to me.
I don't know. Katriana makes all our deals. Ask her.
Typical big folk indifference. Okay, be that way.
Not even some fellow halflings? Okay, then, be that way.
Oh. Well, never mind, then.
Because Katriana's our leader. She's the one that makes all the deals wherever we go.
Sure did. We're used to defending our caravan from bandits and the like. They took us by surprise though, sneaky critters, so a few of us got hurt.
They ran off out of town, but I don't know where. Torias chased after them, so he'd know more, I guess.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Yeah. What's so funny about that? We beat 'em off, didn't we? You see anyone around here do any better?
You big 'uns are all the same. Sure, go ahead, laugh. We still beat 'em off all the same.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
I agree. That's an awfully strange thing for a halfling to say. Shame on you.
The name's Furten.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
And that's my brother, Birgen. He doesn't talk much.
Ho there, big 'un. Careful to watch where you step, as there's halflings about. We tend to get underfoot, so you big 'uns keep telling me.
Oh, you know... big folk. Tall people. Like yourself. No offense.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Never you mind with that, brother. These folk seem decent enough.
Don't you mind him none. He's had a bad day. Well, we all have, actually.
Ho there, friend. Always nice to see another halfling in these parts.
Hah! Katriana says you're going to be joining us in the desert, friend.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Now that's not a very nice thing to say, brother. I'm sure <he/she>'ll be fine out there. We'll look after <him/her>, we will.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Oh, yes we will! Heh... don't mind him, friend. He's never cared for the Anauroch very much, nope.
I've got to go.
Mind if I ask you a few questions?
Have you seen any kobolds leaving town recently?
This is some kind of halfling caravan, then?
Who's in charge, here?
Where are you headed next?
You look more like wanderers to me.
Are you a bunch of thieves?
What happened here?
So the kobolds didn't rob you?
I'll do that.
Is there a reward in it for me?
I've no interest in helping anyone.
I already spoke to Katriana.
Why can't I talk to you?
You defeated them, then?
Halfling might? You're kidding, right?
Who are you?
Err... big 'uns?
Does your brother have a problem with big folk?
Is there something you need? I don't have time to chat... my mates here need tending to, as I'm sure you can plainly see.
Right, then. Fare you well.
The name's Katriana. I lead the caravan. Why? Who are you?
Oh, but mine is? Funny, but I remember saying I didn't have time to chat. Was there actually something you needed?
Ha! For a halfling, you're pretty secretive. Have it your way, I guess. Was there something you actually wanted?
Alright. <FirstName> it is. Nice to meet you. Was there something you wanted from me?
<FirstName>, eh? Well, what was it you needed from me exactly, <FirstName>. As you can see, my hands are full.
That so? Dwarven wizard, right? I think I remember him. He's come to give me messages to take on to other towns, sometimes. Pays handsomely.
Very well, then, <FullName>, apprentice to Master Drogan. What is it, exactly, that you needed from me?
If you make it quick.
I did, as did my grandfather before me and his mother before him. Why? Something odd about that?
Well, we trade, mostly, moving from town to town around the Silver Marches. Occasionally we'll range farther west... but not since the plague in Neverwinter.
We're wanderers, for the most part, but I daresay we do well enough as merchants that we're welcome most anywhere.
Not lately. Such are the fortunes of plying your trade in the north, however.
Somewhat, yes. We're always looking for guards, however, and the boys don't do so bad when they're not surprised like we were today.
I'm thinking we'll try crossing the Anauroch desert. There's goods out east that'll bring a grand price when we head back this way.
We can always use another guard... so I can't see why not. But we're not going anywhere until everyone's recovered.
Try back later. I'll know our plans for certain, then.
We can always use another guard... so I can't see why not. But we're going to need some time to stock up on supplies.
Not at the moment. We came to Hilltop to get supplies... and the kobolds took off with much of what we had stored. Sad day, isn't it?
You mean since the ones that robbed us ran off? No, sorry. I've been busy here, however... maybe you should talk to Torias or Furten. They've been on watch.
Attacked by kobolds, naturally. Seems obvious enough, doesn't it? They came out of nowhere and tried to rob us.
They didn't get away with anything important. Well... that's not true, exactly. They took Daschnaya's cards, sadly.
Maybe you could. They're a simple pack of fortune-telling cards, but they've been in Daschnaya's family for generations.
If you get the chance, we'd sure appreciate getting those cards back. We'd even reward you. Not that I expect much. I bet those kobolds are long gone.
As you wish.
Torias might. He followed after them a bit when they ran off. Maybe you should talk to him.
They're used for telling fortunes. That's what Daschnaya does... her family's been at it for generations. It's a sad thing to have lost her family's cards.
Our fortune-teller. She makes a bit of coin at the towns we stop at. Her family's been using those cards for generations... it's a sad day that we've lost them.
They took Daschnaya's cards, but thankfully those have been returned. Otherwise we're fine.
You could get Daschnaya's cards back. I'd consider that a service.
Uh-huh. Well, maybe you can be, at that. We were attacked by kobolds earlier, as you can obviously see.
Ha ha! No... no, I think I have everything I need. But thank you.
Yes, they certainly are. As I already said, those are Daschnaya's cards. If you bring them to her, I'm sure she will be very pleased.
Here... I see you've misplaced the key for her wagon. Take this and go to her, please.
You'll find her in the northern wagon. If I were you, I'd take her up on a reading if she offers you one.
How did you...? No, never mind. Obviously you took those from the kobold thieves, themselves. I hope you gave them what they deserved.
Those cards are indeed Daschnaya's. Out of everything the kobolds took from us, these are all we really wanted returned. I'm sure Daschnaya would be grateful to have them back.
Here... this is the key to her wagon. If you're lucky, perhaps she'll give you a free reading!
Good. Thank you again for this. Things are looking up, for once.
Good. Thank you again for this... perhaps you big folk aren't so terrible after all.
Daschnaya's a fortuneteller. It's in her family's blood. So far she's never been wrong.
Suit yourself. I'm sure she'll reward you, regardless.
All she said is that it was important we came to Hilltop, and that we'd be fine. And we are, I suppose.
Maybe she did.
Well... you can talk to her about that. They're her cards. If I were you, though, I'd ask for a reading.
Right behind me. Daschnaya hasn't been in the mood to come out since the attack. This should cheer her right up!
No doubt. I'm sure whatever big folk cleric they have here in Hilltop is busy enough with his own people. Besides, I haven't the coin to pay for spells.
Thank you, but I have the situation well in hand. I'd rather not be indebted to anyone; it's not our way.
I don't wish to owe you big folks anything, so no thank you. We'll make do. Not that I don't appreciate you offering.
I appreciate the offer, friend, but no thanks. I'd rather not be indebted to anyone. It's just our way.
Thank you. Was there something else you wanted, friend?
Maybe so. You may not understand it, but our self-reliance is very important to us. We only ask for help when we really need it... and that's not now.
So, then... is there something that you actually need from me, or can I return to my work?
They aren't going to die. I have the situation well in hand, thank you very much. You may not understand it, but our self-reliance is very important to us.
Perhaps not, but I would still owe you nevertheless. You may not see that as much, but we do. As I said, it's just our way... nothing personal.
You're joking, right? I meant that these fellows are my good friends as well as workers on the caravan.
They were injured by them bloody, sneaking kobolds and that means we're going nowhere until they're well.
Hullo there, friend. You'll have to excuse me if I can't stop to chat for long... my mates here need tending to.
You again? Did you forget to ask something the first time?
Hullo again. Have you had any luck finding those cards? That's getting my hopes up a bit high, I suppose, isn't it?
Nobody. I was just asking. It just seems a shame for Daschnaya to lose something so precious to her.
Nobody. It was just a simple question. Must you big folk get sensitive over everything?
Well, I wasn't expecting much. Like I said, those kobolds are probably long gone.
Anyway... is there something in particular you need?
Have you brought those cards to Daschnaya, yet? I'm sure she's eagerly looking forward to getting them back.
We don't tend to look much to others for help, but... thank you kindly. I appreciate what you did for Daschnaya.
Look... I don't know if you're looking for some payment, but I didn't ask you to heal anyone. We can make do on our own.
Not for any healing, I'm not! We didn't ask anyone in town for any help, so if you're just here to "offer" your services then please go back.
I don't mean to sound ungrateful, but we don't tend to look to others for help. It's just our way.
We owe you a debt for bringing those cards back... even though you have yet to give them to Daschnaya. For that, yes, but not for any healing.
We owe you a debt for bringing those cards back to Daschnaya. We'll always be grateful for that... but I didn't ask you for anything else.
Well... I suppose this does speed up our recovery a bit. We don't have to stay here any longer than we have to.
I... thank you. We're not used to having others help us, that's all. I don't mean to sound ungrateful.
Now, if there's nothing else, I do have to attend to the others...
So is there something else you needed?
Err... and I admit we would all be very grateful if you brought those cards to Daschnaya.
Especially considering what you did for Daschnaya. You're always welcome amongst us in the caravan, friend.
I... well, I see. You struck me as a <man/woman> who was going to charge me for something I didn't ask for. I see I was mistaken.
I understand you're to join us when we cross the desert. We're about to start preparing for the trip... are you ready to go?
Fine, fine. We won't be staying around forever, though, so don't dally too long.
Excellent. I assume you won't object to helping us load up one of the wagons? Let's hop to it.
I should go.
Who are you?
My name isn't important.
Just call me <FirstName>.
My name is <FullName>, apprentice to Master Drogan.
Mind if I ask you some questions?
You said you lead this caravan?
So what kind of caravan is this?
So you must be pretty wealthy...
Isn't all that traveling dangerous?
Where are you off to next?
Would it be possible to join you on the trip?
Do you have anything to sell?
Have you seen any kobolds pass by lately?
What happened here?
Maybe I could be of help to you in getting them back?
I have some other questions.
These aren't the cards you're looking for, are they?
Does anyone know where those kobolds went?
What's so important about some cards?
Who is this Daschnaya?
You mean these cards?
I was just hoping I might be of service to such a pretty halfling lass.
Are these cards yours?
I'll go find her now.
What do you mean by 'reading'?
I don't believe in any of that.
And she didn't tell you about the kobold attack?
Maybe she should have foreseen she'd lose her cards.
I was expecting a reward.
Where is this wagon of hers?
Why not see a cleric? A few healing spells and they'd be fine.
I can help heal your men, if you like.
As you wish.
That seems like a stubborn attitude.
If you'd rather your men died, that's up to you.
Really, it's no trouble. You don't need to repay me.
Your mates? All these men are your husbands?
Who said I was looking for them?
No, I haven't found them.
Are these the cards you're looking for?
You're indebted to me whether you like it or not!
Well excuse me for offering a hand.
I didn't ask you for anything... I was just trying to help.
I could heal them, too, if you like.
Who are you?
Not just yet.
Yes, I'm ready to go now.
Wait... are these cards yours?
The dust on the ground has been disturbed heavily by small tracks... kobolds, without a doubt.
These appear to be kobold tracks. You cannot determine how many of them, but they seem to have gone into the cellar.
These appear to be kobold tracks. Three of them seem to have gone into the cellar, but not come back out.
A small group of creatures passed through this area recently, according to the tracks.
A small group of humanoids seems to be inhabiting the small cave in front of you.
A small group of orcs, perhaps six, appear to use this cave as their home. They would appear to be fresh, indicating that some of them are in the cave at this moment.
<StartAction>[The wolf looks at you with a lopsided grin.]</Start>
The wolf remembers the smell of blood on the wounds of the kobolds that ran into the cave.
The wolf scratches at a fleabite, wondering if swimming in the river would be worth the effort to get rid of the pest.
The wolf appears bored and wonders when you are going to go hunting together.
The wolf looks you over to decide if you would make a good mate, arriving at the decision that you would not produce good offspring together.
The wolf complains about a stag he was hunting that kept disappearing into thin air.
The wolf wonders how you can stand to move about on two legs, since you are obviously much slower.
Hello, wolf.
The lock on this cage appears too solid to pick and the bars too thick to break.
These tracks are from some kind of deer. You cannot tell how fresh the tracks are.
These stag tracks are growing familiar to you, but you still have not seen the mighty beast that is responsible for them. You do feel like you are drawing closer to your elusive quarry.
These appear to be deer or stag tracks, but from one you are not familiar with.
These stag tracks must be from the Shadow Hart. These tracks seem quite fresh. Your quarry must be close.
These stag tracks are growing familiar to you, but you still have not seen the mighty beast that is responsible for them. You do feel like you are drawing closer to your elusive quarry.
These appear to be stag tracks, but they are from an unusually large one. One you are not familiar with.
These stag tracks were from the mighty Shadow Hart.
You are unable to determine what creature made these tracks. They do seem to generally be leading in the direction of the pass to the Nether Mountains.
These appear to be kobold tracks. They seem to be leading to the High Pass to the Nether Mountains.
These appear to be kobold tracks. A large group of perhaps 30 or so of the creatures passed by this way within the last day. They seem to be leading to the High Pass to the Nether Mountains.
The rat quivers in fear at your approach.
The rat appears to be shocked at your presence in its mind. You feel the quiet, safe darkness of the passage which the rat calls home.
Although the passage is quite large, the rat has lived there many years and feels quite comfortable. The rat worries that you are here to steal food from the giant as well.
Finally, he scurries off in the never-ending quest for food.
Hello, rat. Where did you come from?
<StartHighlight>[Behind this pile of rocks you see a small, darkened crawlspace that leads out to the foothills.]</Start>
<StartHighlight>[Behind this pile of rocks you see a small, darkened crawlspace. A possible escape route - if one was to brave the darkness.]</Start>
<StartAction>[Crawl into the darkness.]</Start>
<StartAction>[Do nothing...]</Start>
<StartAction>[Grab Becka and crawl into the darkness to see where it leads...]</Start>
<StartHighlight>[Behind this pile of rocks you see a small darkened crawlspace that leads back into Rumgut's cave.]</Start>
The tunnel seems to have collapsed behind you. There is no way back into the cave from here.
<StartAction>[Do nothing...]</Start>
<StartAction>[Crawl back into the cave...]</Start>
I gotta do my chores. Leave me alone.
Hey, what are you doing in here? I suppose Nathan is looking for another farmhand. Well, just watch yourself and don't go thinking you can just waltz in here and replace me.
I am the top farmhand for this homestead. Hey, wait, you look familiar. Are you that weakling that started the fight at the Bubbling Cauldron last week?
Uh... oh, sorry, goodbye.
Well, my friends aren't here right now. Why don't we see who is best?
He is an old, pathetic failure and I bet he made up all his adventures too!
I like to cut little beasts, it's true. Maybe you would like to be my next victim?
Try dropping to your knees and praying that I don't send you to meet your pathetic god!
Your voice is like the croaking of a toad, even when you talk!
Keep your weapons out of it and we shall see who is best!
What is this all about? Why are ye fighting with our guest? If my Nathan judges <him/her> to be good enough to enter our home, then ye will treat <him/her> as an honored guest!
Aw, Toli, it was all in fun. A little harmless bravado... er... right, <FirstName>?
Nathan will dock your pay, lad. Now get out of here and get your chores done.
Yes Toli. <StartAction>[Grumble, grumble.]</Start>
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Well, he can be very short tempered, but he really is a good farmhand, and we do be needing him. But he does need to be punished.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> I never did like the way ye skulked about here, lad. Ye can just get off our property and we'll see about hiring a new hand.
Someday you will all regret this! Especially you, <FirstName>.
Hmm, well, you had better get outside and get your chores done boy, before Nathan comes back in.
Yes Toli. <StartAction>[Whispers]</Start> Thanks, I owe ya.
Oh, sorry about that. You sure look like that chump though. Anyways, I better get back to my chores. Goodbye.
You have the wrong person. Goodbye.
And I would have won that fight, if your friends hadn't interfered.
You insulted my teacher! Drogan's powers deserve your respect.
You and your friends were bragging about your cruelty to animals. It was the least you deserved.
You insulted my god in public! What else was I supposed to do?
You are the one that made fun of my music! I ought to teach you a lesson in manners.
That's right, you cowardly dog! I bested you then and could take you again!
He's right. It was all good spirited humor.
No. I have never been so insulted.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> No, this brute is a violent, evil man. You should get rid of him.
I suppose you could call it that.
No, you have mistaken me. I am one of Drogan's pupils.
Talk to Nathan, he's the boss around here. I have chores to do.
Good to see the rescuer of me daughter back in me lands again. I hope all goes well for ye.
I see ye be back and me little girl is not. I hope ye have some idea of how desperate me situation be.
Aye, be on your way then.
I am sure ye are, <lad/lass>. Tis just hard to be the worried parent with no recourse but to wait. Good luck to ye.
Take those words back! Do not utter such things! Me girl cannot be dead, tis a lie to unman me! Gods no! <StartAction>[Sob]</Start>
Go from me. I must needs be alone. Thank... thank you for returning to tell me though. Now go, and leave a man to his grief.
Aye, that be true, but I had hoped that a pupil of Drogan's might have a change of heart and do the right thing. I guess I was wrong. Be off with ye then.
Ho there, stranger! If ye come lookin' for treasures, just keep on goin' for ye will no find easy pickin's in this home! Nathan Hurst has a spirit more fierce than a dozen wolves.
So tell me who ye are and where ye be from, that I might know if ye be friend or foe!

Aye, I be Duergar, at least in flesh and birth. But me soul is just dwarven, simple and pure. I be married to a shield dwarf, and if she can find the strength to forgive me race, I expect no less of others.
And if ye do not trust that, then ye can visit the village of Hilltop and speak to me old friend Drogan. Now who else can have such noble company to vouch for them, I ask ye?
Be gone stranger, or I shall bury your corpse in a shallow, unmarked grave. I have neither time nor patience to deal with close-minded fools. Wait, have I not seen ye before?
Now I recognize ye. Somethin' about your face was pullin' at me mind, but I am too distracted by my own troubles to recall ye, <FirstName>. We have never met, but I have seen ye from a distance.
Drogan would not have mentioned me, as I asked him not to speak of me, lest he get himself into trouble for befriending one of my kind.
What honest person could be passing through in this territory? Wait, now that I get a better look, I recognize ye, <FirstName>. Ye be one of Drogan's pupils.
That be truth in any land, but it sounds like the wisdom of me old friend Drogan. And now that I get a better look at ye, I recognize ye, <FirstName>.
I occasionally buy supplies in the village of Hilltop, and now that I hear your name I think I remember ye. A student of my old friend Drogan's, if I be not mistaken.
Ah, Drogan! Well do I know the old dwarf. We have shared a glass or two on a cold night. I think I remember ye now. I saw ye from a distance when I was speakin' with Drogan.
Be welcome then, but know that ye come in hard times, and look not to me for great hospitality.
Ye will find that difficult to do, <lad/lass>. I shall bury your corpse in a shallow, unmarked grave and not trouble Drogan with the troubling truth about his wayward pupil.
That be just as well. When a man can no longer protect his own, it be best not to offer protection to others.
Well, there has been some trouble from the wee scaly folk, but there always be trouble from one group of monsters or another. We defend what be ours, with little worry for them.
Aye, there has been some trouble from the wee scaly folk, but there always be trouble from one group of monsters or another. We defend what be ours, with little worry for them.
The reason this be a dark time is that me daughter, Becka, has been kidnapped and I cannot leave me pregnant wife, who be so close to term.
The babe could come at any moment, but I swear to Chauntea, when the child is born, it shall have hill giant for supper. That drunken oaf Rumgut will rue the day he turned to villainy.
If ye happen across a hill giant cave, be sure to kill him swiftly and free me girl, Becka. I can promise ye a reward, though not much, I fear.
Aye, go right ahead. I don't promise ye no answers though. Too much on me mind to be thinkin' of ought else.
Will ye help me with me daughter, Becka, or are ye too hard of heart to care.
I hope ye will find me daughter soon. Goodbye.
It is to the west of here. Just keep your eyes open and ye shan't have much trouble finding it.
Aye, Chauntea might be human, but she represents all that I have become, so I invoke her name when I mean somethin' to be true.
She favors farmers and fertility, two things I quite depend on in me newest profession. There be precious few dwarven farmers, and damned few Duergar ones, but I figure she'll have me.
I changed me name, for safety reasons. Some of me kin were huntin' me and I figured that takin' a human name might throw them off the trail. So far it seems to have worked.
Tis a long and unpleasant story, let me assure ye. Drogan and I started off as enemies and we fought several times before we ended up in a situation where we were forced to work together.
I will not tell ye all the details, but we ended up trapped in a tomb with a bloody lich. The cursed thing would have killed us both, but we managed to escape by settin' aside our differences.
It was Drogan who convinced me that there could be a better life than the one my race has chosen. Times have been rough, but I have no regrets now. That be all I have to say. Anything else?
I never asked ye to care! I was merely speakin' me mind out-loud. So, since ye seem bored by me tale of woe, ye might as well be gone. But I will tell ye one thing.
Ach, there be this hill giant called Rumgut, on account of his serious drinking habits. Despite bein' a bit strange, he actually made a fair neighbor, as he never got along with goblins.
Never had any serious problems with him until now. Two days ago I be milkin' me cows when all of a sudden I hear me daughter screamin'.
I go runnin' just in time to see Rumgut run off with a sack over his shoulder. He took her to his cave which is somewhere in the hills to the west. Would ye be willin' to help me poor child?
Ye should watch your tongue, <lad/lass>. I am in the kind of mood where I would cut it out with nary a pang of guilt.
Now be off with ye. I do not need your kind of black thinkin' around here.
That be as I feared. Let me just say that if ye do happen to find yourself in Rumgut's cave, if ye save me daughter I can promise ye a reward.
If ye do not, then it shall fall upon me own shoulders, just as soon as me babe be birthed.
Aye, I hope ye have a change of heart, <lad/lass>.
I can offer ye a reward, though I will have to think on what I can give. I have little gold these days. Still, I shall think of something worthy of me daughter's rescuer.
I see that Drogan has trained a fine, young <lad/lass>, indeed. Go to the west and ye shall find his cave.
Be careful though. He might not be the smartest fellow, but he still be strong, like all his kind.
I remember seeing you with Drogan one night, about six months ago. I was quickly bored by your discussion of agriculture; a dull topic for a famous adventurer.

Xanos, I remember that. You interrupted one of our fireside conversations. We were speaking of you and the other pupils, not real agriculture. Drogan thought he had found a good "crop" of seeds in you four.
I remember seeing you with Drogan one night, about six months ago. You were discussing planting and harvesting, which seemed an odd topic for someone like Drogan.
Ah, Dorna, yes, you interrupted one of our fireside conversations. We were speaking of you and the other pupils, not real agriculture. Drogan thought he had found a good "crop" of seeds in you four.
Ah, me little girl has come back to me and she tells me that I have ye to thank for it. Do not be thinking that I do not recognize how hard ye worked for it.
I have a reward for ye. A little something I picked up in me old adventurin' days. Try this on for size and see if it be a worthy gift.
Ye will always be welcome in me little home. If ever ye need a safe haven to rest, just come on back, me friend.
You are a right, fine <lad/lass>, and ye always have a welcome in this home.
How dare ye threaten me little girl! That act will be the last of ye, I promise ye that!
Leave me be, that I might grieve for me daughter. And if ye would do a kindness, pray that me second child be born healthy and strong.
Goodbye.
I am trying.
Your daughter is dead.
Explain what happened.
I have decided to help you.
I want to ask you some questions.
I didn't say I would help you.
Aren't you one of the dwarven race known as the Duergar?
You lie; I know all about Duergar and their evil ways.
I am Drogan's pupil and he never mentioned you.
Well, as a matter of fact, I know Drogan well.
You have no need of a name. I am simply passing through.
Recognize a friend by <his/her> face; words can be lies.
The people of Hilltop know me as <FirstName>.
I am <FirstName>, a pupil of Drogan's back in Hilltop.
I'll just take what I want off your corpse then.
No trouble, good Master Hurst. I am not here to stay.
What is bothering you so greatly?
Have you been bothered by the kobolds too?
Good luck and goodbye.
I just want to ask you some questions.
That's all my questions.
Where is the hill giant's cave?
Why did you mention Chauntea? Isn't she a human goddess?
What kind of name is Nathan, for a dwarf?
How did you, a Duergar, come to live on the surface?
I don't care about your troubles.
Tell me more, perhaps I could help.
Forget it. She's probably already been roasted on a spit.
I have my own problems.
Goodbye.
I changed my mind. I will help you.
Is there a reward?
I can help you.
<StartAction>[Whispers]</Start> Please, ye have got to help me! I must get out of here. The stench alone is almost enough to kill me.
No, do nae hurt him. He is nae evil, just misguided. He has actually treated me fair. He also helps protect the lands around here from goblins and kobolds.
I mean, if ye have to kill him, then I suppose I can live with that, but I would surely like it if ye would try another way first.
My name be Becka. I be the daughter of a farmer who owns a small homestead not too far from here.
I was out doin' me chores, when Rumgut comes runnin' up, grabs me and throws me over his shoulder and carries me up here.
He had never done us any harm before, but for some reason he got it in his fool head that he just had to have a wife. And since I be the only female around these parts, I was the unlucky pick.
I do nae wish to be a bother, but I would rather not spend me life here, serving a drunken giant.
Me father would surely give ye a reward for settin' me free. I have nothin' to give ye, meself.
He be attached to me somethin' awful, but perhaps you could persuade him to let me go, or perhaps get him drunk. He does drink many a bottle of rum.
Good luck.
No...<StartAction>[sob...sob]</Start> Please, do somethin'. Anythin'.
I suppose that if ye leave and wait for his next meal. I can cook him a big pot of kobold stew. He do be very susceptible to falling asleep after supper. Ye would have to be very quiet though.
What do ye mean a special powder? Like a poison? I would nae want to kill him. I am sure I can get him to sleep without it.
Ye be the rescuer, I suppose I must follow your lead, whether I agree with it or no. I will take your powder then.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Well, as long as he will no be hurt, a little extra caution be the smart way to go. I will take your powder then.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> <StartAction>[Choking powder destroyed.]</Start>
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> I will take this. Leave and allow me to make the meal and then return.
Well, ye be free and I be in here. I am afraid I be out of great ideas. See if ye can come up with somethin' better.
Alright, I will add as much seasoning as possible, to make him gorge himself. Remember, be silent when ye return and come speak quietly with me. I will tell ye where he puts the keys.
What are ye doin' back here? Are ye mad? Rumgut will get suspicious.
Yes. Please do.
I can nae believe ye came stompin' in here like a bloody ogre and woke him up. The point of our little exercise was for you to sneak in here.
I can nae believe ye got yourself thrown in here with me. When I first saw ye, I thought a rescuer had come at last. Now you be just another mouth to feed, or maybe the next main dish.
So how do ye imagine we will get out of this little predicament, might I ask?
Ahhh! A rat! Kill it, kill it!
Ah... you be right. I thought that the rocks over there were just from a bit of a cave in. I never thought to check them out.
Ah... I do nae know. I thought that the rocks over there were just from a bit of a cave in. I never thought to check them out.
First, kill the rat, please.
Ah, fine. I will put up with the rat, if there is the possibility we can escape.
I hate rats! They are so dirty and they bite. Oh, please just kill it!
Oh, thank you. Check where it came from too. Maybe there be hope after all.
When I saw ye were a fellow dwarf, and male to boot, I began to get all sorts of romantic notions in me head. Ah, what a fool-headed lass I turned out to be, as me father would say.
Please, let us hurry and get out of here.
<StartAction>[Whispers]</Start> Thank ye, but please hurry and open the gate.
Good, please be quick.
What? Nae now! Once we are out of here, then we can speak. Hurry <man/woman>!
I will follow ye down there. It can nae be any worse than staying here with the stench of old Rumgut.
Thank ye for savin' me life. I thought I was goin' to be stuck, married to that giant with his huge belly and tiny mind forever.
If ye go to me father's farm in the east, I assure ye, he will want to thank ye and give ye a reward.
What? But... but... no! How could that be? He was fine the last I saw him!
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> That is a hard jest to stomach. I do nae wish to be near ye. Come to my father and he will give ye a reward.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Ye... ye lie. I can see it in your eyes. Ye killed me father and now ye would kill me.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> No! I... I will go and find out who did this. I will track them down! They will pay, I swear on me life, they will pay!
I will kill ye, horrid beast!
Well, we be out of the giant's grasp, what other trouble could there be?
No! I shall not go from horror to another. You horrid beast!
I cannot let you terrorize this child, a kin of mine, any more. Let her go.
I think we could use the reward more, <FirstName>. She would only slow us down.
You... oh, ye two must be joking. That's not very funny though. Come see my father and you will get your reward.
Thank ye again, kind <sir/madam>. I did need to be gone from there.
I can nae ever thank ye enough for the rescue, me friend. Should ye ever come back this way, I do hope ye will stop in and have some good cheer with us.
Thank Vergadain, Rumgut finally passed out. Now hurry, I saw him drop the key to the cage over by his mat.
Rumgut... he is nae sleepin'; he be dead! Ye tricked me into killin' the creature. Ye should have told me what would happen. T'was a wicked thing, killin' the fool giant.
Let us get out of here quickly. I nae want to see his corpse lyin' there.
I wish Rumgut had cooperated and just let me go. I had no desire to see him dead, but even less to remain here. I think he might have carried the key to the cage or its over by his mat.
I'll have nothing further to do with ye.
Thank ye for savin' me life. I thought I was goin' to be stuck, married to that giant with his huge belly and tiny mind forever.
If ye go to me father's farm in the east, I assure ye, he will want to thank ye and give ye a reward.
Right, I will just kill him.
Who are you?
Let me see what I can do.
What is it worth for me to do this?
What am I supposed to do with the giant right there?
I'll be right back.
That might work, but it might not. Any other possibilities?
Actually I have some special powder <StartHighlight>[choking powder]</Start> here. I could give you some to put into his food.
Do it my way, or I won't help you!
<StartCheck>[Persuade - lie]</Start> It won't hurt him, it will just help him sleep.
I changed my mind. Let's try it your way.
<StartCheck>[Craft Trap]</Start> <StartAction>[Use choking powder to make a poison.]</Start>
Let's try it your way then.
I don't like that plan. I think we should try something else.
Let's give that a try.
Right. I'll be back later.
What am I supposed to do again?
Fine, I'll go kill it.
That wasn't in here a second ago.
Where did it come from though?
I'll go look, but I won't kill the rat.
Why do I have to kill the rat?
Alright.
I'll get it.
Maybe we should talk first.
Your father is dead.
<StartCheck>[Persuade - lie]</Start> Sorry, bad joke. He's fine.
<StartCheck>[Persuade - lie]</Start> I don't know how it happened.
I had to kill him. Now, back to business.
Who said you were safe?
You are right. I will meet you at your father's farm.
I think I would like to kill you now.
There is a reward a young, female like you could give me.
I think I could use a personal slave.
I will meet you there then.
Ah, what I would give for a nice jug of dwarven ale! I will never have another child again, I swear it!
A week overdue! When will this child come?
Gah! I have known cows who weighed less than I do now! This is why I did nae want another child for so long.
My husband will nae tell me what is going on. He wishes not to worry me, but I am sick with worry, nonetheless.
Me precious daughter! Where be me daughter?
Ah, I want this child out of me! I am so sick of being this heavy and awkward.
Ah, it be so good of ye to have brought Becka back to us. Now she can help me have this child.
I can feel something be wrong with me daughter. I think her life has passed from this mortal coil.
Ye are evil, pure and true. Ye shall pay for your deeds!
The pure white stag stares at you, its flanks heaving, and its thoughts skittish. The one thought that stands out is an image that is quickly translated into a name, Shadow Hart.
The stag watches you go nervously.
<StartHighlight>[The stag calms down and tilts its head slightly, in a friendly gesture.]</Start>
The stag gazes at you curiously. It seems unsure of what you want.
The stag gives its head a shake, snorts and eyes you to see if you have anything else to say.
The stag dips its head and forequarters in an attempt at a bow, then bounds away.
It snorts and paws the air, showing you a spot of blood on its hooves. Obviously it is no friend to what it considers annoying, little reptiles.
The stag stares at you, not comprehending your question. To it, all creatures are separated into those who hunt and those who are hunted. It clearly views itself in the second category.
Images and feelings brush your mind: cold wastes, peopled by barbarians and shadowy wolves, as well as creatures of myth that have not been seen on this plane of existence for millennia.
More: fear of large open spaces, where packs of hunters and dogs drag their prey into the ground; love of the close, shadows of the trees, with the protection and shelter they offer.
And the last image, the strongest image, a giant tree, with green energy pulsing out, like nothing you have ever encountered before.
The image of the tree comes clearer to the stag's mind. Creatures of all sorts surround the tree and bask in its magical radiance, filled with a sense of safety and joy.
Then the tree grows dark and brittle and the creatures begin to war on each other. The tree shatters and the stag is no longer sure where it is.
This world is a foreign place, where the stag has been stranded for centuries. The images fade and the stag looks at you with watery eyes.
The stag allows you to touch it, emanating a sense of peace, before bounding off.
The stag calmly watches you approach. Just as you move to attack its eyes grow large and frightened.
The Shadow Hart regards you warmly and you feel a deeper connection with the earth, then it quickly disappears. Something inside your soul tells you that Shadowhart is now safe.
<StartAction>[Walk away.]</Start>
Run Shadow Hart, hunters are near.
Be calm. I am a friend.
May I ask you some questions?
That's all the questions I have.
Goodbye.
Have you seen any kobolds?
What are you?
Where do you come from?
What was this tree?
<StartAction>[Calmly approach the stag, and touch its forehead.]</Start>
<StartAction>[Calmly approach the stag, then attack it.]</Start>
