You seek a harmonious kingdom? I wouldn't have thought...
You should create happiness for its own sake.
You weren't *that* troubled.
What are you saying?
Good. You were never really destined for greatness.
Are you giving up now?
Then what am I destined for?
Indeed...
That doesn't sound very selfless...
Self-preservation?
If those sorcerer-kings are all gone... do you think it's a good idea to follow them?
You're building your base on the tyrants of old?
How so?
Where will you go after you have finished learning? What will you do?
I wish you luck in your journey.
How barbaric!
A modest beginning.
Your empire and mine will clash eventually, you realize.
Maybe I'll come and visit you someday.
I don't want to hear any more of this nonsense.
Good luck with that, then.
You'll try to conquer a city?
I think you'll need to work a bit more on it...
A people person? Don't make me laugh.
You want to rant a bit more about yourself? Your path to power?
You realize that eventually I'd have to kill you...
I've had just about enough with your egotism.
Seeking power for its own sake is not a good goal.
How would you be better than any of the others?
The only way to real power is to crush all who oppose you beneath your heel!
You'd actually be a decent person, then?
So you'd lie to them to keep them happy?
Perhaps you will do something useful.
It's a wonder an incompetent like you could think up something like that.
A simplistic theory.
You overestimate yourself, yet again, Xanos.
Basically, you just want to be king.
How can you possibly think you'd become so powerful?
Why such a craving for power, Xanos?
Is there nothing else in your life?
It's always good to have a goal... if, perhaps, an inappropriate one.
You're pretty mouthy for a henchman.
A budding tyrant...
Absolute power corrupts absolutely.
I never said you were a monster!
Smarter? What do you mean?
You're pathetic.
Again?
How do you plan to keep it then?
You will never have more power than me!
Sounds kind of obsessive to me...
So you were picked on as a kid... so what?
Are you going to tell me how you ended up at Drogan's now?
You could try explaining, you know.
You tend to get wrapped up in yourself a lot...
Just get on with it.
Some people never change.
Unlike now...
Don't be so hard on yourself.
Everyone has things they regret doing.
Some people never change...
Cry me a river.
So they drove you out, did they?
Let's see this 'true might' then.
Well, 'mighty Xanos', shall we continue?
I am not impressed.
You're kind of funny in a plotting-to-take-over-the-world kind of way.
So how did you end up coming to Drogan in the first place?
You're right... It isn't very interesting, I guess.
You know, this attitude is really getting old.
More likely you'll be remembering *me*!
You sure think a lot of yourself, don't you...
Do not let your obsessions consume you.
I've heard enough of your monomaniacal ranting!
You're set on this path?
What has shown this?
And what is this destiny?
What about the past? It is gone.
The power shall be mine alone!
You should learn not to abuse power...
Whatever it takes? Anything?
Would you believe I'm interested?
Just humor me.
No, not just yet.
Yes, come with me.
It wasn't exactly intentional.
Heurodis will die, plain and simple.
We should bide our time.
Heurodis called it Undrentide.
Maybe it's better if you remained behind.
Fine. But remember what we're here to do.
No. You definitely need to stay here.
Come with me, then. We've much to do.
Maybe so. Don't get any big ideas, however.
I am not a slave, no matter what Ashtara thinks.
A 'thank you' would not be out of the question.
Try not to look her in the eyes again, then.
I won't let it happen to me again.
It's good to see you, too...
I think I can do just fine on my own right now.
That would be a good idea.
I'm going to head out and look for master Drogan's stolen artifacts, but he suggested I take someone with me.
If you really have a problem with it, I'll check with the others.
Yeah, I think you do.
If you see him, tell him to go ahead and talk.
What is it you want, exactly?
You seem to talk on behalf of this Xanos quite a bit.
You? Or Xanos? I get confused.
Yes, poor Xanos.
I'll have to remember to thank him for the sympathy, then.
I don't have time to listen to you now...
And what does Xanos wish to say?
I will find anything valuable, don't worry.
And why are you so interested by who made it?
Who could have made this?
Ancient magic?
You can't be so sure.
You mean...
Perhaps what?
So?
What do you mean?
What's the problem?
We do what we must.
If you want to be a coward, feel free.
Don't worry; I'll be fine.
If you don't think you can handle it...
I don't know.
Then we must retrieve them no matter what!
If I could harness that power...
If only master Drogan could tell us more...
We will proceed with caution then.
It doesn't matter. We must get those artifacts!
What are you suggesting?
I'm not afraid of the kobolds!
What do you mean?
Getting cold feet, Xanos?
You're concerned about elven tombs?
Stop being such a wimp and let's get going.
I'll protect you, don't worry.
We won't die, Xanos.
You think I care what you want?
Why so vehement, Xanos?
We'll all have revenge for what they did to master Drogan.
I would think that people here would be more enlightened.
Then we shouldn't waste any more time here.
Don't get all sentimental.
So you will protect them?
He was always a kindly old man... the fool.
Not everyone only sees what's on the outside.
Well you have to admit: you are a brute.
Don't be so bitter, Xanos.
I was never a pet student!
I've worked harder than any of you!
Maybe we should return to master Drogan...
Whatever you say, Xanos.
We shall find them together.
You always were an egotist Xanos. Don't overestimate yourself.
We should have a plan before getting in over our heads.
Then we should get going!
We may not get another chance...
I don't really care what you have to say.
Death is always a possibility.
Our victory is assured, don't worry.
You will be welcome to travel by my side.
I don't need you to beat Heurodis.
As you should.
Thank you, Xanos.
What is it?
If they haven't, we're lost.
Would the Asabi know?
We'd better be on our guard then.
Where would they be in the city then?
I don't need any Winds to defeat Heurodis!
Of course they did.
It doesn't matter if it'll work or not... she's going to try.
We won't fail. Remember destiny.
Maybe where she fails, I can succeed.
Let's hurry up then.
It will all be mine!
Our task is more important than that!
Then let's get to it.
You're right. It's too old.
Why not?
Don't be such a weakling.
It's hard on me too.
What do you mean?
You would think he would have sacrificed you instead.
There is nothing that can be done now.
He gave his life for everyone.
Maybe he just lied to make you feel better.
We must honor his memory with our deeds.
His spirit is watching over us, Xanos.
HAHAHAHAHA!
You're a henchman. Shut up and hench.
I am more than capable, Xanos.
Then we have to kill the master.
The mythallar will be safe with me.
We can't allow that to happen.
I don't like it either, Xanos.
And what am I supposed to do about it?
So why did you come, then?
Quit your whining, Xanos.
I've wondered about that, myself.
What would you rather we be doing?
You don't think that's important?
If we know why she wants the crystal, we might know how to defeat her.
And just where would we look for her?
You make a lot of sense.
Well, we don't seem to have a choice, as you said.
We also stand to gain significant rewards.
What? Are you afraid of a little danger?
There's a stinger behind you.
Master Drogan is a Harper, and we are helping him.
Perhaps I could have refused. Too late now.
I think you underestimate the possibilities here.
Are you kidding? This is an adventure!
I owe Master Drogan a lot. This is the least I can do.
I want revenge, plain and simple.
Oh, joy.
You like hearing yourself talk, don't you?
Is that so?
Don't force me to kill you, Xanos.
Complain silently, then, if you must.
Let's go.
Stay here.
This is some sort of lens that one could use, but what it is supposed to reveal is a mystery.
Snowy Pine Tree

Shadows of Undrentide
This module was designed for 1-4 players of levels 1-7.
Xanos could use some of that kind of encouragement too.
After the way you treated me when I first came to town? I do not think so, half-orc.
There is an image that will take me years to wash from my mind. Disgusting.
<StartAction>[Blushes]</Start> Oh dear, I did not mean for you to overhear that.
They have a bad reputation, but this one does raise some interesting prospects. It's not as if the village couldn't use a little more tax revenue.
If this fool could become the mayor of a village, just think how much more Xanos will accomplish!
Ah, violence should always be a last resort, but sometimes it is necessary. As you seem to be good at problem solving, I think we shall become fast friends.
Discount?! Now there is a word I like to hear!
The Red Wizards have some powerful magic items, this is most fortunate for us, <FirstName>.
I always knew Veraunt was a fool. This could help Hilltop grow into a powerful center for trade.
I see your friend has a quick mind. She is correct, and I told the Mayor as much.
Hah! Spoken with a sharp wit! I have great respect for those who know how to wield power. It is unfortunate that your people's reputation for evil is so well known. Xanos will not make such mistakes.
Those of my generation are working hard to overcome the reputation of our past. I am glad to know that some of you paid attention in your classes.
Xanos always pays attention to important details.
Hmph. Tell me when you are finished fraternizing with tiny little men, <FirstName>, so we can get on with the business at hand.
Fraternizing, eh? Is the big lug jealous?
Jealous? Of you? Ha ha ha ha! How utterly amusing!
Yep. Jealous, just like I thought. Sad, sad thing.
You're a bit of a cheeky halfling, aren't you?
Hah! Maybe just a little bit, my good lady dwarf! Perhaps you'd care to join me, yourself, in the enjoyment of some fine wine, hmm?
Sorry. I make it a policy never to date men whom I could crush accidentally.
Oh? It'd be a pleasant enough way to go.
Flatterer. You say that now. But enough... we've business to speak of.
Oh. Well, then, have fun!
Have fun!
Hmph. Why do you waste time speaking to such insignificant fools, <FirstName>?
Insignificant, eh? You just call Torias that because you can't attract a woman to save your life, I suppose?
Don't be ridiculous!
Yep. Just like I thought. Sad thing, that.
All of them. But I am sure <FirstName> wishes more than a simple kiss, foolish girl. Ha ha ha!
All of them. Trust me.
Ha ha ha haaa! Whatever you had planned, <FirstName>, Xanos is sure it is not going to happen now!
Mmm. Just wait... he gets more suave as the day progresses.
Xanos!
Hey!
A deal is a deal. I can respect that.
You are letting them go, <FirstName>? Pfah. Foolishness.
Hmph. You would think one might be grateful to be saved from kobolds...
Ah, well. It was a nice try, <FirstName>.
Hmm. You wield that hammer like a dwarf. It's no wonder they ran off.
Now that's a compliment if I ever heard one. Thank you, Dorna.
Perhaps the others thought that you might smother them in your over ample bosum and ran away?
It's a possibility. Or is that just you wishing out loud, Xanos? Ha ha ha!!
I... <StartAction>[shudder]</Start>...
You are a rather strange woman, Fiona. I guess that's why I always enjoyed your company.
And I enjoyed yours, little thief. I have even forgiven you for that short sword you borrowed.
You knew... oh... sorry.
Xanos finds you to be an odd, yet exciting woman; so large and strong.
You are also a powerful personality, Xanos. You are one of the only half-orcs I have ever met and liked.
Actually, I would have to agree with Fiona here, I would never pay so much for Xanos. I might pay that much to see him locked in a cell, however. Hmmmm...
I take exception to that! Xanos is worth far more than a mere 2000 gold!
This is pointless, <FirstName>. Why do you bother? Gah.
We still can, dear woman. You say he is here, somewhere?
Your mother escaped from slavery, then?
Yes, but not for long. She died of disease years later, and both Glendir and I were raised by an aunt. She did not... approve of Glendir.
Hmph. I suppose your mother was rewarded to him, as well?
Better than the fool who had to be blindfolded and drugged to spend the evening with your mother, Xanos.
Heh. Xanos likes this woman, <FirstName>.
Pff. Leave it to the elves to build something only to forget it.
I've heard tell of Ascalhorn. That's an ancient place, long ago destroyed. I knew it was in this region, but I had no idea it was near here.
Hmph. Do you elven types not simply intervene in the business of others out of force of habit?
Perhaps so, but now we've two trails to follow instead of just one. Ah, well.
So did the gnolls kill them all or what? Tell Xanos!
No doubt. That could not have gone well for the kobolds. Gnolls are large and fearsome creatures.
Hmph. If the elves have abandoned this place, perhaps they will not mind if we help ourselves to its treasures, eh? We can deal with any... protections.
So Ascalhorn was near here. That's an old tale even by elven standards, <FirstName>.
Very smooth, <FirstName>. Nicely played.
This one is hardly worth arguing with, <FirstName>. He is more dense than you, hah!
I am a dwarf too, giant. I am as big as I will ever get.
Maybe me lock you in cage with wifey. Then we watch you grow with her.
Alright... shutting up now.
Bah! What a horrid noise this creature makes. Xanos can carry a tune better than him, and singing is not my forte.
He is... really big. Let's play this carefully, <FirstName>.
I would call him the god of pathetic fools. I notice you never heal adventurers for free. I guess your generosity only extends so far.
In other words, you got lazy and complacent, so now you are suffering for not spending more time helping the suffering. I love irony.
I don't see us ever finding much common ground, follower of Vergadain.
Last month this prophet told me that my future was carved in stone and even a hard heart could not prepare me. Let us not linger near him long.
Last month he was predicting that I would be eaten by a white dragon. What a fool.
Impure thoughts? That's not what the tavern gossip says.
Impure thoughts? That's not what the tavern gossip says.
That would be the ones that came from Drogan's, without question. So they left by the gate, eh? Good. We can follow them there.
They left by the gate? It somehow seems wrong that they would savage the town and then leave politely by the front door.
<FirstName> is full of all kinds of bravado, never worry.
What do you know about anything, fool? Hmph.
Hmm. Are you a true fortune-teller, then? Or a fake? Because if you're a fake I'll be quite disappointed.
No matter what I say, good dwarf, you shall decide for yourself anyhow.
That's what they all say. I hate that.
Be careful, <FirstName>. This one's as batty as they come. Xanos can tell.
Ah. And you are without a doubt the selfish half-orc. I am pleased to meet you, tall one.
Yes, yes. How very perceptive of you, teeny woman.
Be careful, friend. You will regret your selfish desires in the end. Mark my words, if you dare.
Are you positive it wasn't the townsfolk who tried to throw a bunch of ragamuffin Vistani out of the village?
Not at all. I'm very certain it was the kobolds. I'm not so certain how the locals feel about rude half-orcs, however.
Better that than trying to kill you.
Well, truth be told they made a fair attempt at that, as well.
Hmmm. Xanos seems to recall Master Drogan mentioning these little merchants. They have been coming through this town for many years.
For generations, actually. It's something like a family trading route we follow.
I've heard mention of this caravan. Master Drogan said these halflings come through here on a regular basis and have for many years.
I wonder if there's a reward in it for us? What do you think, <FirstName>?
Make sure you ask her for a reward up front, <FirstName>. These halflings will rob you blind if you give them half the chance.
It would take someone with more arcane knowledge than I possess to tell you the exact value and properties of this item.
That is a lot of gold, but should we really do this, <FirstName>?
I only ask because we might have need of the powers of the hand later. It is a large sum of money though, so I don't blame you if you do sell it.
Are you sure we should be doing this, <FirstName>?
I only ask because we might have need of the powers of the hand later. It is up to you though. Muddle through things however you like.
Why shouldn't I?
Afraid of what Drogan might say?
Why shouldn't I?
Afraid of what Drogan might say?
That was a great sacrifice. I well know how one comes to the point where a principle is more important than loyalty.
Xanos shall have such power and more, but he shall not make the same mistakes. Xanos knows how to learn from the past.
Giant spiders? There had better be a great reward for fighting them.
Poisonous creatures, just what Xanos needs! How I wish my constitution were more suited to fighting off such things. The reward had better be worth the effort.
I will help you.
Yip, yip, grrr! Why you comes here? Who be you who so tough that you comes past barricade?
Hah! Now is our chance. Choose your words carefully, <FirstName>
<StartAction>[Whispers to you.]</Start> Choose your words carefully and we could walk out of here without a fight.
Their eyes gleam with intelligence, but their mouths prove the eyes wrong.
I always heard that kobolds were clever. Obviously there is a difference between clever and smart.
Then... then we must make the trek westward towards Silverymoon. I can only hope we will all survive to see it.
Fare you well, my <lord/lady>.
No... no, I can't let you do this, <FirstName>. Hilltop is fine, all of you... go there and they will surely give you safe haven. <FirstName> is... mistaken.
I see. We thank you both, then. I hope you are right... we shall try to make it to Hilltop now.
Hee hee hee... <StartAction>[snicker!]</Start>
Then we must chance that Hilltop still stands. I can only pray it is so.
Hmph. These folk come from Blumberg, eh? Well maybe they should have defended their village better.
So these are the last survivors of Blumberg. How very sad.
This is pointless, <FirstName>. They cannot even reward us! Look at them! Let us move on.
Oh, come now, <FirstName>. Surely we can let these poor people free, at least.
Well, that's new, at least. I wonder if we can negotiate with him?
Pfaugh! If only it could learn to do so without spitting quite so much!
Be silent, mongrel!
May we kill him now? Xanos grows weary of these stupid gnolls.
Oh, let's kill him, <FirstName>. Please.
What is this J'Nah? Xanos has never heard of female gnolls ruling a tribe before, power or no.
This J'Nah... she is a gnoll? That doesn't sound like a very gnoll-ish name.
There are ruins beneath these caves? How interesting. Perhaps this J'Nah came here for the ruins and these gnolls were just incidental to her plan?
So there be ruins underneath the caves. That makes more sense. No self-respecting sorcerer would live in such dirty caves willingly.
Bah. She wants the same thing from the artifacts as she does from the ruins. Power, of course. They say she is a sorceress, after all.
Smells like an elf but isn't one? A drow, perhaps? One would think even a gnoll could recognize a drow, however. How odd.
So this J'Nah has one of the artifacts for certain. That is good to know.
Only one of the artifacts, eh? It figures.
I hope you didn't actually think you were fooling anyone.
Hah! Here it comes.
But we're not the gnolls, obviously. Why lie to us?
Well... you *could* have been with the gnolls. How was I supposed to know?
You thought we were with the gnolls? Now that's just rich.
Maybe not. But we could still kill you. That would be better than listening to any more of this prattle.
So... you want them to help us fight the chieftain, <FirstName>? And that's supposed to be helpful? Well, I suppose we'll see.
Bah. I am so sick of kobolds. Could we not just kill them and be done with it?
Hah! Now that would be an interesting match; you should go for it!
<StartAction>[Snicker]</Start> Now there's an interesting proposal!
Ah, this explains so much. You must be <FirstName>, the <race> student of Drogan's. You see? I have done my research.
What power that would be! If only one could find a way to harness such power for more than a single use!
Now we are fighting dragons? What do you think you are getting me into, <FirstName>? Of course, if we can survive... just think of the rewards.
<StartAction>[Whispers to you.]</Start> Ah, <FirstName>, I have a bad feeling about this. Watch her eyes; she has the fire of a demon burning in them, indeed.
<StartAction>[Whispers to you.]</Start> Ah, <FirstName>, I have a bad feeling about this. Watch her eyes; she has the fire of a demon burning in them, indeed.
Now this is a sight I just have to see. We have got to help this little fellow.
<FirstName>, I am getting rather tired of kobolds. I just wish they were a touch smarter; more like me than you, hah!
This is going to be good!
This Xanos must witness. Maybe there is a practical use for kobolds.
That's rather noble of you, <FirstName>. If this creature keeps its word, Hilltop could be safe for a very long time.
Hmph. That is a waste of rewards, if you ask Xanos.
Oooo... Xanos is suddenly filled with excitement!
Bargaining with a dragon, <FirstName>? Your call.
An interesting justification. Xanos could hardly do better.
It is not a justification, half-orc. I do not need one to act as I wish.
Indeed. Xanos could only hope for such power one day.
Do not hold your breath. Now... where was I? Ah, yes, speaking to the <race> one.
A rather interesting justification for your betrayal, dragon. Not that I object. Indeed, it's only too bad the two of you haven't killed each other already.
Are you still speaking, little dwarf? I find your <master/mistress> to be much more entertaining, so be silent.
<He/She> is not my <master/mistress>, dragon. We are comrades, and I'll speak as often as I wish.
Such bravado. You would almost think I couldn't hear your dwarven heart beating like a cornered rabbit's. No, I will speak to your <master/mistress> now.
Hmph. Perhaps you should have tried a student with a few more wits, dragon.
And would that be you, little orc? Are you casting about for a new master?
Xanos can think of worse things than to learn of his power from the greatest of Faerun's races.
My my, quite a sly tongue you have there. Almost as quick as Deekin's. Too bad the boy was such a slow learner.
Not much has changed, as far as I can see.
Oh? How about I twitch a little in your direction and see how the famous dwarven stamina holds up, hmm?
If you wish. I refuse to be intimidated by you, lizard.
Yes, yes, how very droll. How the other races must be thankful your kind bury yourselves underground. Now... where was I? Ah, yes, Deekin. He was a slow learner, indeed.
The machine has been fixed and has been used to raise the boulder blocking the passage leading to Tymofarrar.
Hmph. He has good point, maybe.
He's got you there, <FirstName>.
That's probably an understatement.
Pfeh. You would nead a lot of anything to really hurts him. Err... I mean... to really hurt him. (Bloody kobold.)
At least until you get there.
Yes. Nice places. Now leave them alone like a good doggie.
You're lying. Pfah! <FirstName>, this creature knows nothing!
That conjures a really strange image. I don't know why.
I certainly hope you weren't thinking of giving up Xanos to travel with vermin, <FirstName>. That would be insulting.
Hey! Standing right here. We don't need his help, you know.
Hmph. Perhaps you should have tried another spell, <FirstName>. Such as Lightning Bolt.
Damn. I was hoping that would be a quick way out for us, here.
Bah! We are not going to negotiate with this creature, are we? Kill it, <FirstName>! Kill it before it irritates me further!
Well, you have to give him credit where it's due. He's not as dumb as most kobolds.
Oh. That is *all* you wish from us, vermin?
I think the little reptile is actually blackmailing us, <FirstName>.
You broke the statue? Is that even possible? Will you give it to us?
You have the tower statue? Hand it over now, you little vermin, before we kill you!
Ahhh! No hurts Deekin! Deekin just tries to talk peaceful!
Hmph. It would be much like having a mouse show up on your doorstep and claim to be a relative, Xanos thinks.
Well, he has a point there. I've always thought kobolds were more dog-like, myself. All that yapping and so forth.
Dragons enjoy power, like any intelligent being. Even Xanos knows that.
Dragons are greedy. I would still like to know how he even found out about them.
I'm not so certain your master would listen as <FirstName> tells him a two-day lullaby, that's for sure.
You hear that, <FirstName>? You only need to speak of the mating habit of orcs to defeat it. Ha ha haa!
So? Why aren't you off writing your story, little vermin?
So you are some kind of jester kobold? How interesting. That doesn't explain why you're here.
Eh? What's this? Another kobold? Shall we kill it now, you think?
By the gods! It's... a kobold. And it apparently wants to talk to us.
Hmph. It is likely story. As in not likely at all.
And you didn't give the gnolls any help here, I suppose?
Xanos cannot begin to guess. You seem very stringy and unwholesomely annoying.
If it was the only way to keep you quiet, even I might be willing to give it a try.
<StartAction>[Lie]</Start> Tymofarrar is dead.
<StartAction>[Lie]</Start> Well, I talked to Tymofarrar...
<StartAction>[Cast Charm Person]</Start> I think you want to give me that statue now.
Take care what you say, <FirstName>. I sense great power within this unassuming hermit.
It did seem rather powerful. I probably should have bought it, but for some reason I can't remember I decided against it. Hmmm, seems strange to me now.
A hermit in the middle of nowhere, selling powerful magic items? This seems more than a little strange.
Not so much more strange than a dwarf with sticky fingers traveling with a <race> <class>.
Not so much more strange than a dwarf with sticky fingers traveling with an <race> <class>.
Well, I suppose that might be true.
Nevermind. I'll walk.
Goblin Note

Master mean to send us down here. He says look for magic stuff. No find nothing! Days and days go by. Mung and Jer all gone now. Me no go back now, master be angry. Me starve, less painful than master's anger. Lever makes pretty light...me thinks pathways with same pretty light safe. Mung and Jer no believe me and now they dead -- they went down the wrong path and burned all up. Me right, but me no fight flying imps by self. Me eat boots now and hope for best...
Goblin Bones
Chapter 1

<FirstName> is one of a select few students to Master Drogan, a famous dwarven adventurer who has retired to the remote village of Hilltop in the region of Faerun known as the Silver Marches to live out the remainder of his years in relative quiet as he passes on his knowledge to the next generation.
Much of <FirstName>'s personal belongings can be found in the footlocker next to <his/her> bed, including the magical Ring of Mystra which Drogan has forged for each of his students. Its range is limited to a mere mile or so, but the ring allows its bearer to teleport to Drogan's side at will... or, when badly injured, it does so automatically. A useful device for training young students, even though the ring has its limitations: the main one being that it requires special "focus crystals" to power each use, voluntary or no. Drogan once showed <FirstName> how to make more focus crystals using a collection of gemstones and a special machine within his personal laboratory upstairs.
<FirstName> has been Drogan's student the longest and is the nearest to graduation... and once that day comes the Ring of Mystra will no longer protect <him/her> from the dangers and adventures <he/she> will face. Who knows? Perhaps that day will come sooner than anyone suspects...
A large mass of spider eggs has been delicately wrapped into a silk sac.
A door this large and solid must protect something very impressive or valuable.

If you seek the one who once suffered here, he is gone. My sisters have taken him on high and console him there, even now.
Goodbye to you, Seeker.

And he with you. It is why I stayed here, awaiting your return. He says to thank you for all that you have taught him by your forgiveness. If you seek the Wise Wind, he said he'd be there when you found it.

And he with you. It is why I stayed here, awaiting your return. He says to thank you for all that you have taught him by your forgiveness. If you seek the Wise Wind, he said he'd be there when you found it.
We have found ourselves an ally, it would seem. A wise choice, <FirstName>.
Through a noble act, your forgiveness, you will have assistance from the one who suffered.
My sisters? They have taken him to his redemption. New laws have been written, the old ones cast away. With proper penitence and sorrow, the sins of mortal life are now forgiven in the eternal.
My sisters? They have taken him to his redemption. New laws have been written, the old ones cast away. With proper penitence and sorrow, the sins of mortal life are now forgiven in the eternal.
Xanos understands now how the power of words can be so strong. We have wrought change with only a few strokes of the pen.
My sisters? They have taken him to his redemption. New laws have been written, the old ones cast away. With proper penitence and sorrow, the sins of mortal life are now forgiven in the eternal.
Deekin could writes new law... um... everyone listens to Deekin, or... um... gets poked in eye with pointy stick...
Making laws like that could lead you to burning in the pits, little one.
His name was Karsus, Archwizard of Netheril. Perhaps you did not know him. He saw the soul of the world, a crime for which the demons held him here, tormenting him for many an age.
Thank you and goodbye.
I had hoped to speak with him.
Why have your sisters taken him?
Who was here?
You understand what I say, do you not? Besides, my slave, perhaps you will find some other way out of here when my foolish thralls cannot. You see why I must keep you under my thumb?
If I ever free myself from this collar, I shall make no small effort in hunting you down and staking you out in the middle of the desert.
You are welcome to try, but I doubt it would do you any good. If you get free of the collar, do not waste your life on petty revenge.
Xanos is outraged that you would keep me in this collar. I suppose that is why you do it, but I am outraged none-the-less!
The collar will not kill you, but it will keep me safe. Your outrage is not my concern.
Oooo! Does Deekin gets free, too?
Naturally. I assume your <master/mistress> will have need of you, though I can hardly imagine for what.
That be good. Deekin need to stay with boss if he goings to finish epic story.
Mmm. Well, if I ever hear some badly-worded mish-mash of a tale about a ragtag <race> hero and <his/her> kobold companion, I'll know where it came from.
See, boss? Deekin makes you famous!
Yes? Speak then, for your master listens.
Perhaps you would like to barter a little? Business keeps one's mind active and one's pockets full...

The same way you speak the language of the Asabi as if you were born to it... It is the magic of the mythal that does it. Either it is still active after all these years or its magic has been launched anew.
Until my thralls have cleared the passageway, I have no business but with you. Ask, my slave, and I will answer as I am able.
It is said to be the breath of life, the wisdom of ages, the sands of time. It is the magic that gave immortality to those who mastered it and allowed entire cities such as this to float on air.

You need only look at the word to know my answer. The powers of the mythal are a myth, a mirage. If those who wielded it were so great, why do these cities now lie buried and forgotten? I seek no power but what gold itself can give.
Perhaps you do, perhaps you don't. The mythal's magic is said to exist outside the very bounds of time itself. I understand as little of it as you.
Let it never be so, for to live in such a world is not to live at all.

That is true but Asabi is what I hear all the same, for it is what I know. When Undrentide still flew, people from a thousand lands flocked to it. Through the mythal's magic all could share their wisdom without hindrance... Slaves and masters, too.

Stories of the fabled flying cities of Netheril have long been told amongst the Asabi. Some have even been found and empires have been fashioned from their riches. I would build such an empire, my slave, and make all the desert fear me.

Three moons ago, I gambled in a tent with a rival merchant friend, the two of us drunk on the wine of the cactus. He confessed to me that in the shifting sands, he had found the uppermost spires of the Lost City of Undrentide.
I did what Merchant Princes do. I let him win at gambling, then tracked him here with a plan to kill him and steal his glory as my own... Someone, perhaps it was you, saved me the trouble.
You sounds much like Old Master. He says he wants power over everything too, but Deekin is now free!
Take a handful of sand and squeeze it tightly and you shall see what comes to tyrants in the desert. When you relax your fist to view what you hold, there will be nothing left but a speck of dust.
What would you know of such things, my little slave? Leave the bothers of politics to your superiors.
Xanos knows what it is to desire such power. Why then do I find the thought growing less appealing? Forgive me... I am not quite myself right now.

These clothes you wear, they mark you as being not of the desert. You would weaken and die quickly. I would get the best price in the gladiator pits of Ammar where you could live out a short and glorious life before you die.
The Asabi? We are the desert kin, the dune walkers... We were here long before your kind and will still be here long after you have gone. I don't know how else to answer you.

You might as well ask the wind of its beginning or insist a grain of sand tell how it got its shape. I am a child of the desert sea and the sunbaked sand. The dune where my egg hatched has long since become another.
Heurodis, is it? Do all your enemies have such pretty names? Come, you must tell me of her.
Very well, but you had best be careful, slave, or your master will come to think the same of you.

The desert brings madness to many and the sands, as you can see, hide their secrets long and well... Alas, you have the misfortune of being slave to a merchant, not a warrior. I will aid you as only a merchant can but, beyond that, I cannot help.

Ah, that would explain the tremors that have collapsed the tunnel and trapped us here... Alas, you have the misfortune of being slave to a merchant, not a warrior. I will aid you as only a merchant can but, beyond that, I cannot help.
If it comes as any consolation, we do not seem to be free of these sands yet. This Heurodis of yours fights against the weight of centuries. Time is her enemy as much as it is yours.
We will need no more assistance than access to supplies. This time she shall not take us by surprise.
Ah, that would explain the predicament I found you in, wouldn't it... Alas, you have the misfortune of being slave to a merchant, not a warrior.
I will aid you as only a merchant can but, beyond that, I cannot help.
Xanos has endured the humbling experience of petrification, but do not expect me to take the humiliation of slavery well!
I expect you will do as you are told, or you will never achieve freedom.
Ha! The stone has not numbed your wit, I see. We found some rival Asabi near you, some cut by blade and burnt by spell but others frozen into stone.
I don't know your beautiful Heurodis, slave, but I am wise enough to know I never want to.
<CUSTOM1001>'s wit never dulls and Deekin writes quickly to keeps up with all <his/her> deeds.
Ten guardians, built of magic and metal, protect the riches of this place. Destroy them all, my slave, and you will have made a friend of your master.

My only promise was that we'd discuss it. Consider that promise fulfilled... In truth I had hoped the passageway would be clear by now and I could free you without concern for my safety but alas, it is not so.

Regardless, you have earned some portion of my trust. Go where you will, explore the various towers, I will not trouble you. And until my thralls have cleared that passage, I will remain here, happy to trade wares with you.
Sadly, a wise decision, for if I were free right now, I think I would throttle you with my own bare hands!
Can you not hear? ...Ah, see how I have already begun to think of you as kin? We Asabi have no ears in the way you know them. Instead we listen with the very surface of our skin.
Once my thralls told me what to listen for, I have heard them waiting there like ghosts. Their whisper still remains upon my skin and that is how I know your task is not yet done.
Once my thralls told me what to listen for, I could always hear them waiting there like ghosts. Now their whisper has faded from my skin and that is how I know you have succeeded in your task.
You mean everybody not hears like that? What you think boss hears with? Big, fleshy bits on side of head?
There is no room for you to lend a hand within the passageway. Let my poor thralls bash themselves silly against the fallen rock. For you, I have grander plans...
We had only begun our explorations when the tremors sealed us in. There are riches untold out there and if I leave this place without them, my rivals will claim them in my stead.
Don't be a fool. Would I bother to summon you from your life of stone for a simple fetch and carry? I have thralls enough for that. I need you to do what they cannot.
Nor do I ask you to be! Hear me out before you speak your disrespect. I have thralls enough to fetch my treasure but I already lost two to the guardians who watch over it.
Some golem-maker long ago did fine business here, it seems. As they explored, my thralls reported ten golems standing guard. I want this place to be cleared of every single one of them.

Then take this key. It will allow you to leave this camp in safety. Should you ever need supplies, I will gladly trade what I have for what you find. See? Kind is the master who does not ask too much.
Ah, now that is a loving whisper to my heart. Before I forget, however, take this key. It will allow you to leave this camp in safety.
Will you have earned your freedom? Is that what you seek, my slave? Return to me when the task is complete and we shall discuss it. I promise nothing more.
And do these plans include me?
I should like to put you to use clearing the tunnel, since digging in the earth is what your race seems to like best...
Not all dwarves are miners! That would be like me saying that all lizards lay around in the sun all day.

I shall forgive you this once for calling me a lizard. Do so again and I shall cut out your tongue. Had you let me finish, I was going to say that you will be most useful assisting your <race> friend here.
And what of the mighty Xanos? Have you plans for him as well?
You made an overly large paperweight, and were far too ugly as a statue. The only purpose I can see for you is to serve your friend here.
Xanos is too weary to argue about who should be serving whom. I will do as you say.
As if you had any choice, my large, monstrous slave. I do like your accent though. Now, where was I? Oh, yes.
You gots plans for Deekin, too?
Hardly. As a primitive thing, you should be pleased that I released you to serve your <master/mistress>. That is what I assume you are for.
Deeken serves boss, yup. Deekin also writer of great, epic tale!
Yes, well. Be that as it may, your place is best kept at the side of your <race> friend, here. Now... where was I? Oh, yes.

The same way you speak the language of the Asabi as if you were born to it... It is the magic of the mythal that does it. Either it is still active after all these years or its magic has been launched anew.
Until my thralls have cleared the passageway, I have no business but with you. Ask, my slave, and I will answer as I am able.
It is said to be the breath of life, the wisdom of ages, the sands of time. It is the magic that gave immortality to those who mastered it and allowed entire cities such as this to float on air.

Let it never be so, for to live in such a world is not to live at all.

That is true but Asabi is what I hear all the same, for it is what I know. When Undrentide still flew, people from a thousand lands flocked to it. Through the mythal's magic all could share their wisdom without hindrance... Slaves and masters, too.
That is good, for I am no man. I am Ashtara, Merchant Prince of the Asabi tribes. We are a little more cold-blooded in our dealings, you might say, and you remain my slave all the same.
I should not have told you my name. Already you use it far too freely. I may be a kind master but I am your master all the same. What is it you would ask of me?

Stories of the fabled flying cities of Netheril have long been told amongst the Asabi. Some have even been found and empires have been fashioned from their riches. I would build such an empire, my slave, and make all the desert fear me.

Three moons ago, I gambled in a tent with a rival merchant friend, the two of us drunk on the wine of the cactus. He confessed to me that in the shifting sands, he had found the uppermost spires of the Lost City of Undrentide.
I did what Merchant Princes do. I let him win at gambling, then tracked him here with a plan to kill him and steal his glory as my own... Someone, perhaps it was you, saved me the trouble.
You sounds much like Old Master. He says he wants power over everything too, but Deekin is now free!

Xanos knows what it is to desire such power. Why then do I find the thought growing less appealing? Forgive me... I am not quite myself right now.

These clothes you wear, they mark you as being not of the desert. You would weaken and die quickly. I would get the best price in the gladiator pits of Ammar where you could live out a short and glorious life before you die.
The Asabi? We are the desert kin, the dune walkers... We were here long before your kind and will still be here long after you have gone. I don't know how else to answer you.

You might as well ask the wind of its beginning or insist a grain of sand tell how it got its shape. I am a child of the desert sea and the sunbaked sand. The dune where my egg hatched has long since become another.
Yes, you probably should. In time, however, you will come to thank me for placing that collar around your neck. As long as you wear it, I am safe from your vengeance and you from your own folly.
I freed you from your stone prison because I have need of you. But need is a blade that cuts both ways. You will find that I am not that harsh a master.
Heurodis, is it? Do all your enemies have such pretty names? Come, you must tell me of her.
Very well, but you had best be careful, slave, or your master will come to think the same of you.

The desert brings madness to many and the sands, as you can see, hide their secrets long and well... Alas, you have the misfortune of being slave to a merchant, not a warrior. I will aid you as only a merchant can but, beyond that, I cannot help.

Ah, that would explain the tremors that have collapsed the tunnel and trapped us here... Alas, you have the misfortune of being slave to a merchant, not a warrior. I will aid you as only a merchant can but, beyond that, I cannot help.
If it comes as any consolation, we do not seem to be free of these sands yet. This Heurodis of yours fights against the weight of centuries. Time is her enemy as much as it is yours.
We will need no more assistance than access to supplies. This time she shall not take us by surprise.

I will aid you as only a merchant can, but beyond that, I cannot help.
Xanos has endured the humbling experience of petrification, but do not expect me to take the humiliation of slavery well!
I expect you will do as you are told, or you will never achieve freedom.
Ha! The stone has not numbed your wit, I see. We found some rival Asabi near you, some cut by blade and burnt by spell but others frozen into stone.
I don't know your beautiful Heurodis, slave, but I am wise enough to know I never want to.
<CUSTOM1001>'s wit never dulls and Deekin writes quickly to keeps up with all <his/her> deeds.

Is it not enough for me to save you from an eternity in stone? You drive a hard bargain, my slave, and it is a good thing your master is a merchant born. You will need supplies and I will need the trinkets of this city to sell in distant lands.
Do not make this hard on yourself. Your life is mine and your body, too - the collar makes it so. Work with me and perhaps I shall set you free when we no longer have need of each other...
Goodbye.
There are other things we must discuss.
Enough questions. I grow weary of them.
How is it that you speak the Common tongue?
Fine, but I still have other questions.
The mythal? What is that?
Do you seek the power of this mythal?
Then I don't have much time.
And if it falls into the wrong hands?
I'm not speaking in Asabi.
What brought you here to Undrentide?
What did you do then?
If slaves are your trade, who were you planning to sell me to?
Who are these Asabi you speak of?
Where are you from, Ashtara?
I need your help. Heurodis must be stopped.
Never mind. You are of no use to me.
She is a madwoman, a vile murderess who I have tracked here.
She intends to raise Undrentide from the sands.
She is an evil medusa, crazed with power.
<StartCheck>[Insight]</Start> She is beautiful. You should look upon her face sometime.
What task did you want me to perform again?
I had expected a little more gratitude for my efforts...
How do you know whether I've accomplished the task or not?
I need supplies.
Very well. If I am your slave, what do you command of me?
Very well, master. The treasures of Undrentide shall be yours.
That's all? You want me to fetch your trinkets and baubles?
I am not a raider of tombs!
Ten guardians? Fine, I shall destroy them as you ask.
Very well, but I'm going to need supplies.
Goodbye.
<StartAction>View Store.</Start>
And if I succeed in that?
How is it that you speak the Common tongue?

I am no man's slave...

I should kill you for your mockery!

Never mind. You are of no use to me.

Death to you and all your kin, slave master!
For these we burn, undying...

Leave.
Read the story that you've written.
[ASHTARA - 40177] So, my precious work of art, we are alone...
[40178] There's more to you than meets the eye, isn't there...
[40179] Oh yes, so lifelike, so unlike the stylized form that was popular in ancient Netheril...
[40180] Here, let me place this collar around your neck... Can you feel that?
[40181] Soon you will... It's a slaver's collar. An enterprising merchant makes his money in any way he can, you see...
[40182] We used to transport slaves like this, as stone across the desert...
[40183] No need to feed you, nor waste our precious water on your parched throat...
[Minor Tremor] [40184] Within the hour, you will be able to feel your flesh again...
[40185] When that happens, my slave, come speak with me in the adjoining room, for I have need of you...
[ASHTARA - 40170] So is it you I have to thank for the collapse of our escape shaft?
[THRALL 2 - 40171] No! The ground - we didn't mean for it to shake!
[THRALL 3 - 40172] We brought you a statue, Master...
[ASHTARA - 40173] I see what you brought me! Why do you think I haven't killed you yet?
[THRALL 3 - 40174] You wouldn't!
[ASHTARA - 40175] Don't tempt me... I want that passage cleared at once!
[THRALL 1 - 40176] Yes, Master Ashtara. [They move to their bashing stations and begin].
[THRALL 1 - 40160] Hey, what's this?
[THRALL 2 - 40161] Ooh, pretty statue...
[THRALL 3 - 40162] Go on, take it! Master Ashtara will be pleased with us.
[Minor tremor] [THRALL 1 - 40163] I don't like the feel of this...
[THRALL 3 - 40164] Fine, I'll take it. Here, help me with this, will you?
[THRALL 1 - 40165] Are you sure this is the kind of stuff Ashtara wanted?
[THRALL 3 - 40166] Is there anything the Master doesn't want? Come on.
[Major Tremor] [THRALL 2 - 40167] Watch out!
[Major Tremor Continues] [THRALL 1 - 40168] Let's get out of here!
[Major Tremor Continues] [THRALL 3 - 40169] Not without the statue!
[Fade to Black]
I'm awake! I'm awake! Man the hatches, we're diving to three hundred feet!!! ...Oh, it's you again, is it? I'm not sure what the recurring dream is anymore: you talking or me falling...
I'm awake! I'm awake! Man the hatches, we're diving to three hundred feet!!!
Nope, I never do, never do... That ought to teach you to let a sleeping rat lie.
Really? Well you've found the wrong rodent! Aren't there space hamsters who do these things? I tried to help once, you hear? A thousand feet, I told them! But did they listen? Oh no!

Cry me a river! We've all got our problems, understand? Now about that thousand-foot minimum: It's a safety precaution in case something goes horribly, dreadfully wrong, you see? The Shadovar kept to a proper minimum...
Old Fireshorts? Don't mind him, his brain boiled off long ago. But he casts a fair bit of light to keep the Shadovar at bay. Besides, he's handy to have around when I need someone to talk at...
Yes, and with an IQ triple your own, I wager, and more gray hairs than you can shake a wig at! Now leave me alone and go play with the Shadovar or something.

Hehe. I bet you thought I was crazy for a minute there, didn't you? Three hundred feet! Ha! That's the kind of tom fool protocol that got us into this mess in the first place. A thousand feet, I told them! But did they listen?
Absolutely! A thousand-foot minimum! Two thousand if you can! It's a safety precaution in case something goes horribly, dreadfully wrong, you see. The Shadovar, they kept a thousand-foot minimum...

Yes, back when my master, High Arcanist whosamacallit, was still alive, one of his students broke off and formed a rival city. The student could have taught my master a few things about safety regulations, might I add...

When all the floating cities of Netheril tumbled out of the sky, this student's city was flying at a safe altitude of a thousand-plus feet, you see: He had time to jump the entire city into the Plane of Shadow.

Oh, goodness knows. He always was a bright lad. At any rate, the shift was permanent and they've stayed there ever since, with the exception of the occasional trip into Undrentide. Call themselves Shadovar, now.

Look, just because I have a ridiculously high IQ doesn't mean I have all the answers, okay? We were rival cities, full of spies and industrial espionage and the like. There's always a back door somewhere.

Regardless, after the crash they pretty much took up residence here in the tower. Now that someone's reactivated the mythal, though, they're getting jumpy. Nobody wants a fall, right? So they're stealing stuff...

Oh, any of my master's magic, I'm sure, and the Dark Wind especially. But, to be honest, they're tearing the entire place apart, bricks, mortar, everything. I guess they mean to rebuild it back at home.
I'm a rat! A smart rat, a talking rat but still a rat! Smart enough to know better than to mess with Shadovar, that's for sure. If the bricks are so important, you go fight them for it!

While you're at it, why don't you just hop one of their handy shadow portals and take the battle to their bloody homeland? What do I care!? Undrentide is dead and gone: that's what you get for bad safety regulations...
I say we kill the medusa, grab as much loot as we can and get out of this city before we are killed!
You make it sound so easy. The problem is, if she gets this thing in the air and flies it close to the ground, it'll tear us all apart. You might want to think on that for a bit.
Xanos would like to see us flying over the ground, rising above all others. It would lift his spirits as much as his body. But only if we control the flying city.
And just how high would you fly the city?
Um... 1000 feet minimum?
At least you seem able to learn. I don't suppose this one who woke the city would be so smart. Maybe you aren't too bad, but I don't trust your <race> friend here.
And besides, this city be all way under ground. Shady peoples just salvages the place.
Well *I* happen to still live here and I ain't the only one! Still, none of us have as many objections as the <race> smarty-pants, here.

Well, you could fall out of the sky, for starters. Then the High Arcanist to whom you're bonded body and soul could die a horrible crushing death beneath a pile of rubble while shopping for your morning vegetables...

After that, you linger, haunted by guilt for untold years, an insipid fire elemental for warmth and company, while Shadovar from a rival (and much smarter) city slowly occupy the school said High Arcanist headmastered...

Then, just when you think you've settled into a morosely pleasant existence, someone comes along and fires up the old mythallar again, no doubt hoping to buzz around the landscape at three hundred feet all over again...
Frightened by the sudden activity, said Shadovar begin to steal everything (bricks, mortar, and the Dark Wind notwithstanding) back to their namby-pamby "Plane of Shadows." And then...
And then, just when you think things couldn't get any worse (what with the Shadovar and all), I find myself rudely awoken and asked ridiculously banal questions by the likes of you!!!
Fine, fine! Commandeer the conversation just when I was getting someplace interesting! That's bloody typical, you know... Something, somewhere always seems to go wrong.

The little magical thingamawhatsits that makes this place tick, as it were. Whoever has it is up atop the Temple of the Winds, if you're interested, though no doubt it's sealed off now that someone's got the thing running again.

Back when I still had any sense of ambition, I poked around up there and tried to put all the mythallar back together. Never could find all of the pieces but it does seem that someone's finally finished what I'd started.
There's a little part of me that knows I'm going to regret telling you this but, as I said, it's little and not particularly bright, either. You see, it's a safety regulation...

When someone's controlling the mythal, it's a pretty big deal and you want to keep them safe from distractions, right? So you seal off the temple... But what if something goes horribly, dreadfully wrong?

You name it, really. A sudden heart attack, interplanar invasion, a fishbone stuck in the throat, spontaneous human combustion (quite common among arcanists, natch), a burning desire to dive to 300 feet...

In situations like that, you need a back door as it were. Hence the Ark of the Three Winds that sits outside of the temple and the three said Winds being dispersed throughout the city in case of emergency.
Well, the Dead Wind is with the... the Cryptologists? Oh, I don't know, the folks in the Crypt Tower at any rate. And the Wise Wind's tucked away in the Library somewhere...
As for the Dark Wind, well that used to be in the possession of my master, High Arcanist what's-his-pickle, but who's to say now. It's all on account of those Shadovar, you see...
If you need to be able to get into a room quickly, you don't keep the keys spread across a city. That seems awfully foolish for such a powerful society.
Hah! You aren't as dumb as you look. Let's just say that hoofing it was not really the preferred mode of transportation in a magical society where teleportation was as common as copper.

Well, that would make getting around a lot easier. Just imagine the things you could steal if you could just sneak in, then teleport out once you had the goods. You are saying they could do things like that?
One would think it was foolish to keep the winds spread around the city, if one might need to get into the tower in a hurry.
Hah! You aren't as dumb as you look. Let's just say that hoofing it was not really the preferred mode of transportation in a magical society where teleportation was as common as copper.
They must have had awesome powers. To bad they were not wise enough to survive. That would save a lot of time, to just be able to teleport wherever you wanted to go.
But... why they spreads winds out all over city? If there be emergency you gots to get into tower quick, no?
Hah! You aren't as dumb as you look. Let's just say that hoofing it was not really the preferred mode of transportation in a magical society where teleportation was as common as copper.
People just blinks about all the time?
If memory serves, yes indeed. That doesn't make things easy, but after a city crashes into the ground one would assume a mythallar emergency to be the last thing on anyone's mind.
You mean that snaky bitch?
You mean Heurodis?
You mean scary snake lady?
You're asking me? What do I look like, a Netherese herald?

What, were you raised in a barn? Are you so unfamiliar with the concept of a school? It's called the Arcanists' Tower. S apostrophe: plural possessive. As in many arcanists, all claiming partial ownership of the same tower.

In short, it used to be a boring old place where they teach you how to blow things up. This is the first floor right here, not much to see. As for the upper floors, they're shadows of their former selves, I must say!
We know plenty about schools, it is where we have just spent a good portion of our lives.
Really? Tell me all about it? I have this deep, abiding interest in hearing all about your youthful mishaps.
You don't have to be sarcastic and rude.
Yes, actually, I do. It is one of my few satisfactions in life. Now, back to my discussion with your <race> leader.
Xanos does not know why, but I always thought rats would be more jovial, less cynical and hostile in attitude.
I'm old and tired. You rolled me off the wrong side of the bed today. Come back tomorrow and I'll be as sweet as a nymph.
Really?
No. Now shut your yap and let me get back to the thread of my conversation with the <race> prime.
Oooo. Did it breaks and you finds little crystal inside?
Keep up with me, boy, or leave me to talk to the <race> prime here, alright?

Yes, old what's-his-name... What, it's been a while, alright! I mean, they have all manner of rules and whatnots in place for what should happen to a wizard when his familiar dies but the reverse? Nothing! Zero! Zilch!
You mean that snaky bitch, Heurodis?
Do I know her name? Was I supposed to have gazed into a crystal ball or found her name etched in the starry sky? How would I know who she is?
How would you like me to cut off your tail?
How would you like me to bite you and infect you with some deadly disease. I am trying to tell you about the repercussions of this! Big repercussions! Are you listening to me?
You mean Heurodis?
Do I know her name? Was I supposed to have gazed into a crystal ball or found her name etched in the starry sky? How would I know who she is?
You are just a rat. I could step on you.
But not before I bit you and infected you with some deadly disease. I am trying to tell you about the repercussions of this! Big repercussions! Are you listening to me?
Rat person talks about scary snake lady, maybe?
You're sharp for a lizard, aren't you? Unfortunately all this shaking has repercussions. Big repercussions! Are you listening to me?
Ummm... yup, Deekin writes it all down...
I'll bet that hurt.
You have no idea.
Now Xanos is glad he never found a familiar he liked.
What kind of inbred animal would want to live with someone like you? I mean, except the <race> kind.
There was this little toad once... alas poor Hoppy, I squashed him well.
That not sound good.
It really isn't, let me assure you, my big scaly friend.
Never mind.
Excuse me, I need your help...
I hunt a medusa named Heurodis.
If you don't mind me asking, what's with the fire elemental?
A talking rat, are you?
What?
And what mess are we in, precisely?
A thousand feet?
Shadovar?
The Plane of Shadow? How did he do that?
If they're trapped in the Shadow Plane, how do they get here?
What are they stealing?
And you're just lying here, doing nothing?
Uh... What could possibly go wrong?
High Arcanist?
Cheer up. It's not so bad...
Dark Wind?
And then...?
Whoa, let's have a change of topic here...
Dark Wind?
Mythallar?
If the temple's sealed, how do I get in?
What kind of wrong are we talking here?
Where can I find these Three Winds?
School?
High Arcanist?
You come too late, heroes! I have already claimed the maiden's soul!
You big meanie! Leave us be!
Ssshhh!
Look but don't touch!
Get out! You don't belong here!
No, nooooo! You're leaving footprints!
My mold! My dust! Mine!
Play NICE!!!!
Meddler!
My dust! Eeeeek! Don't disturb my dust!
Fresh ink still glistens on the ancient vellum.
The ink that once covered these pages has all but faded away, leaving a pale, blank surface.
You dip your quill into the bottle of ink and begin...
It doesn't take you long to write your tale. You lay down your quill, satisfied.
You can't think of a story to write. Perhaps you'll have to come back later.
Leave.
Write a story to catch the Wise Wind.
"In a darkened wood..."
"Beside a calm oasis..."
"Amidst a raging blizzard..."
<StartCheck>[Insight]</Start> "Where treasure lay buried along a storm-lashed coast..."
Leave.
Read the story that you've written.
Write a story.
Interlopers? Kill them at once, sisters!
Blood stains the pages of this illuminated manuscript. It appears to be a religious treatise of some sort.
You dip your quill into the bottle of ink and begin. It doesn't take long to make the necessary revisions.

Read the treatise.
You tire ssso quickly of our conversssation? Do I not hold your attention asss I once did?
What would I have need to ssshare for? Sssee how powerful I have become? I will not trussst you, nor anyone. I am sssssupreme!
This is the power Xanos once wanted. Now I find myself repulsed by it, and by what you have become.
I can sssee your doom, half-orc, yesss, sssoon.
Can you see me holding your severed head in my hand?
No, I sssee your doom though, sssoon, yesss.
Ooo... maybe you sees if Deekin's friend Raklig the bat be fine.
I sssee your doom, little one, yesss.
Enough talk.
Let us work together to conquer the world. It should be large enough for two to share.
Your evil ends here and now!
I have heard enough. It is time for you to die.
I came to kill you, not to banter.
The mythal will destroy you. Let it go...
You have lost your gaze that turns men to stone?
You are mad! Return this city to the sands where it belongs!
What does the mythal let you see, Heurodis?
